story:
Flexible solution for my problem

Hello I am Rasto (or Visiohand :-) from Slovakia. Led underlighting is my great hobby. When I finished the  underlighting  of my ceiling with low installation height, I saw the errors on edges of the boards with overhang. So I need to  hide these defects on shaped and bent drywall and hide the led strip. Profiles that are on the market can bend only to some extent and require wet processes to finish and are very short for bigger lighting zones. So I decided to try out my own solution for this problem and create something more than just a profile. Solution with specific shape, construction and material. Something simple, cheap and new.

 some defects on the drywall corner. 

THIS IS LEDLEM SOLUTION AND LEDLEM ATMOSPHERE

THIS IS LEDLEM PROFILE

Examples for using the LEDLEM: for drywall constructions in interior, for exhibition stands, advertising, for creating solitaire lamps, underlighting thin frames, boards, TV and so on. Everywhere where is a plate with overhang and you want to hide the edges. Please see the examples in our gallery. And if you get bored with effect you can exchange it for another. Or you can buy custom LEDLEM with your idea (text, name, symbol, silhouette, pattern, idea with which we'll help you) . It is simple. 


First 50m of LEDLEM

At first we need to produce 50 m of LEDLEM prototype but it requires the mold.  We would like to produce this mold in our country so we can take more control over the quality.

first 50m of ledlem with LED strip


After that we can go to the next steps.

What will we do with the funds if the campaign would be successful ?


From the 4th step we are planning to develop a LED strip with motion effect - LEDLEM survive with LEDLEM zone controller (or LEDLEM SMART controller) and application for smartphones with many effects for sharing. With this controller we can bring more live on your wall (see the sample in video gallery) and control all lighting zones. 


We want to work on LEDLEM step too. The profile and led strip for ground lighting with motion sensor. LED illuminates according to how you move around the strip. It may be very useful on stairs. 


All elements should be compatible and then they will be able to create even more effects. For example, we see the movement behind the wall with LEDLEM survive and LEDLEM step. Or you can make impressively clock. You can also connect to the TV for live ambient lighting, simulation of flashes, wind, waves..and etc.. Light atmosphere is unique..

Next we want to start to sale the final LEDLEM set and LEDLEM creation kit. We would like to do it before the end of 2015. Then we will be ready to fulfill our promises. 

final LEDLEM set for 50m and 5 lighting zones

final LEDLEM creation kit with custom plate until 50x50 cm

If the campaign is not successful, we will not stop working on it. At least in the first 50 meters of ledlem. 

Of course we appreciate each contributor that will help us to achieve this dream. Each contributor will be rewarded. Our rewards might look like this.

The Impact

LEDLEM is designed to beautify your living spaces, your interiors and companies. Simply wherever you want to use LED backlighting. LEDLEM creates illuminating flat graphics / silhouettes and unique atmosphere in your area. LEDLEM is quick and cheap realization of Drywall constructions with or without LED backlight. LEDLEM is flexible, colorful and creative as well as our world and life is.  


I believe we will find supporters especially among designers, architects, builders but also among smart and handy people. For less skilled we have prepared the LEDLEM creation kit. 

Risks & Challenges

We are at the beginning. We have no prototype and sponsors. Development of the final product will take longer time. Despite of it, I'm sure that this is the right way and this product is worth it. Here are the most important challenges in the development and implementation of our ideas.

EPILOGUE :-) FINALLY

We know it's the specific product. Nevertheless we hope, that many people will join us through the great atmosphere of light. Maybe they will evaluate the possibility of realization their own ideas without great cost. We have so many ideas for the use and improvement of the product. But without your help and support it will not be probably possible. 

We are grateful for any contributions, comments, sharing and even criticism which we hope will move  the product to the successful final. Big thanks to all contributors! And thank you for the opportunity INDIEGOGO.

We are at the beginning. We have no prototype and sponsors. Development of the final product will take longer time. Despite of it, I'm sure that this is the right way and this product is worth it. Here are the most important challenges in the development and implementation of our ideas.




EPILOGUE :-) FINALLY
We know it's the specific product. Nevertheless we hope, that many people will join us through the great atmosphere of light. Maybe they will evaluate the possibility of realization their own ideas without great cost. We have so many ideas for the use and improvement of the product. But without your help and support it will not be probably possible. 





We are grateful for any contributions, comments, sharing and even criticism which we hope will move  the product to the successful final. Big thanks to all contributors! And thank you for the opportunity INDIEGOGO.

story:
Short(ish) Summary

Hey y'all,

My name is Penn Johnson. I'm a new-age hippie folksinger & storyteller focusing on modern day slavery, a changing climate, child abuse, feminism, sea-level rise, fossil fuel addiction, drugs, alcoholism, depression, and all the peaks and valleys in between. I'm raising money to record my first album 'For The Trees' and cover costs for my first Anti-Fracking Music Tour.

Sophomore year of college, I learned about fracking and tuned into climate change. Junior year I studied abroad in Australia and learned about sustainability and environmental action. When I got back, I founded Franklin & Marshall College's Fossil Fuel Divestment campaign and started focusing my writing on the environment and man's place in nature.

I graduated college without a job. My friend told me about an opportunity to work on the frontlines of fracking. There was no real funding, only a roof over my head and food in my stomach. That was enough for me, so I packed my bags and headed to Northeast Pennsylvania.

Summer into Fall of 2014, I spent 7 months on the frontlines of hydraulic fracturing or "fracking" in the shalefields of Montrose, Pennsylvania working as a journalist and photographer with Energy Justice: Shale Initiative. After a while, I realized that the articles and reflections I was writing were estranging me from the rest of the people who weren't on the frontlines––I was losing my audience.

Since music is the universal language, I figured that people who aren't as knowledgeable about the dangers of fracking would listen to and learn from music if it were presented as a story. So I started writing more music. I continued writing when I left the shalefields and eventually, I'd written enough songs to record an album (and still some 30 more, yet to be recorded).

Now, I'm on an Anti-Fracking Northeast US Music Tour to raise awareness and spread the stories that inspired me to get involved and care about the earth and the future generations who have yet to experience nature's beauty.

20% of the proceeds from this Campaign and my Tour will be going to another Campaign for an impacted Pennsylvania landowner who is suing Cabot Oil & Gas in Federal Court. (Link to that campaign coming soon!)

example of the last song on the album:


What I Need & What You Get


To cover the cost of recording the album and the tour, I'm asking for $5,000. This cost covers:

  • musicians who appear on the album ($550)
  • mixing ($800)
  • mastering ($800)
  • 300 CD printed albums ($650)
  • Digital Distribution ($90)
  • food and gas during the tour ($1,410)
$700 extra allows for merchandise and unexpected tour costs.
Logo artwork: Nick Nazzaro
Album Artwork: Mike Bailey
The Impact

By supporting this campaign you are directly helping impacted landowners in the shalefields of Pennsylvania as well as supporting my musical endeavors, which allow me to continue to educate and inspire people in a fun, creative, and universal way.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't donate, doesn't mean you can't help. Please share this campaign with your friends, family, ex lovers, current lovers, spouses, extended family, resident owls and forest creatures, that one family member you never talk to because of that one time that thing happened.

story:
Don't ask me who that character was though, after all it's been long and forgotten but a memory as good as gold. Worthless but all the same the world to me.

I love to draw and was recently rejected by the school of my dreams. That won't stop me from feeling down and about though! Since 2015 started, I vowed to work harder on anything and everything I do.

I love to do detail! Don't mind the smiley face though, that was a friend's doing.

This wreath was done on A6 paper using a 005 Sakura Micron pen.


My name is Natalie Chan, 18 years old, artist/student/instagrammer/child.

Foxes are my bae and 'go-to' whenever I'm in a rut.

Spiders scare the heck out of me, but these guys are pretty cute haha

You see, I never once stopped dreaming the wild, and since finding other amazing artists on crowdfunding sites (and sharing their passion with the world), I'd like to share with everyone the oddities I encounter each day in my doodles as well!

I'm a stranger with an addiction to learning.
I'm a dreamer who wishes she can be a polyglot.
I'm an artist who never grew up.

What is this campaign about anyways?

For just $2 CAD, I will send out a random A5 sized (4.13 × 5.83 inches) doodle page. This will be filled with anything from Super Heroes (Marvel/DC), Anime characters, Pokemon, Animals, Fairy-tales, life drawings or even a combo of any of them! These will mostly be done in colored pencils.

All artwork will be done on paper from this booklet!: http://www.muji.us/store/stationery/notebooks/r...

I'd like the rights to the drawing!

Unfortunately, I'll have to say no. All designs and art will either go to the rightful licensed creators or to myself. That means that if I do like a piece that I sent out, I'll most likely be taking a picture of it to retain rights and post them here and there on my website. 

This crowdfunder is just for fun and a cute memory for you amazing people who support me!

Can I ask for a specific colour or theme?

Yes, yes, yes! If there is definitely something you like or dislike (or a colour preference you have even), please message me about it through indiegogo or hellochuguri@hotmail.com and also comment with your name and perk that you've purchased. Otherwise, everything will be done in random!

Can I purchase multiples of one perk?

Of course :) Just multiply the cost of the specific perk as many times as you'd like and add it on when donating/paying!
(i.e $2 x 5 drawings = $10).

The wreath is so pretty! Are you offering those too?

Yes, you can purchase one through one of the Perks! They cost $35 to do as they are quite time consuming to do. I will also be doing these on A6 sheets versus the regular A5 (which is half of an A5 paper).

Are you offering Digital Art as well?

The drawing at the very top is indeed a digital doodle! I haven't been doing much digital art so this time around, I'd like to say no. Perhaps it'll be a perk later on? Depending on how things go!

If you ARE interested in commissioning me, please email me for rates. Thank you!

One of my most recent and favourite commissions! This will cost regularly $20.

Where is the money going?

All the money accumulated from this project will be put into art supplies, education (I will be attending University in a couple of months!!), and postage stamps and envelopes. Indiegogo will also be taking a portion of the money from the campaign.

P.S

I was inspired by this pretty amazing guy here:

https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1751781738...

Go support his kickstarter! (I know I will!)

story:
Short Summary

The Wings of Eos emerged from the artist's desire to pay homage to those who help others to begin again. Formed around a pair of Fibonacci spirals that connote a heart shape, the Wings nod to the patterns connecting us all. The sculpture will be installed as a shrine at the 12:00 doorway in The Temple of the Golden Spike (Man Base) for Burning Man 2017.

The "feathers" that comprise the Wings are handprints traced and lasercut from four generations of the artist's matrilineal line. These handprint feathers are being decorated by friends and family as well as by pARTicipants at events like Precompression. Thus, these Wings are pure hands-on art, a truly collaborative experience.

The hope and aim of the Wings of Eos is to remind those who pass by of how they are supported by those around them, of the possibility of starting over, and of the strength and power that comes from connection.

The Wings of Eos received an honorarium from the Burning Man organization, for which our Team is deeply grateful. The honorarium is estimated to cover about 1/3 of our cost, so we need your help in order to bring this piece Home.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To finish the piece, we need an additional $2500. This will go toward:

  • Wood, wood, and more wood (nearly 1000 handprint feathers plus structural wood)
  • Art supplies
  • Construction supplies
  • Tools
  • Safety equipment
  • Packing and transportation costs

Here are what your donations will gift to this shrine alongside the awesome little perks we offer to thank you for your support:

  • For $10, we can make 16-20 handprint "feathers."
    • If you support us at the $10 level, we'll give or send you a handmade necklace with an inscribed "Wings of Eos" handprint "feather," either to be delivered on-playa (if we know and/or can find you) or mailed in October.
  • For $25, we can make 50 handprint "feathers" or buy one sheet of structural plywood.
    • For support at this level, we'll send you a lovely pair of wooden handprint "feather" earrings. These will be mailed in October. 
  • For support at the $30 level, we'll send you both the necklace and the earrings!
  • For $50, we can build 1/4 of the structure of a wing, seal 1/4 of a wing to protect the feather-art from the elements, or buy a top-quality router bit to cut big structural pieces on the CNC router.
    • If you support us at this level, we'll send you something really special: an LED-illuminated wooden necklace crafted from a handprint "feather" and inscribed with "Wings of Eos." If you choose this perk by August 15, we commit to delivering (on- or off-playa!) or shipping this flashy-blinky thing to you before the start of Burning Man so that you can wear it out on the playa at night! We will be offering 30 of these only.
  • For $100, our team can spend a day at TechShop, where we cut and assemble structural pieces as well as feathers.
    • To thank you for your gift at this level, we'll send you a framed 5x7 photograph of the Wings of Eos on-playa, to be delivered in October along with a wooden feather necklace.
  • For $250, we can purchase 1" maple plywood from which to cut the main Fibonacci support brackets as well as the base. This amount of support also goes a long way toward safely packing and transporting a Wing to the Playa.
    • To express our gratitude for your support at this highest level, the artist will custom-craft a beautiful pin for you in celebration of hands-on art. It will be approximately 4"x3" and made of tiny handprint feathers cut that will be colored, decorated, sealed, and layered as they are on the Wings of Eos. This gift will be delivered in November. What a great holiday gift for those who support collaborative, hands-on art! Only 6 available.
  • Contributions in any amount are most welcome!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this campaign far and wide to help us reach our goal. Thank you so much!

  • Please join us at Man Base at sunrise on Tuesday of burn week for a healing and meditation ritual ceremony marking the gifting of the Wings of Eos Shrine to Black Rock City.

It will be approximately 4"x3" and made of tiny handprint feathers cut that will be colored, decorated, sealed, and layered as they are on the Wings of Eos. This gift will be delivered in November. What a great holiday gift for those who support collaborative, hands-on art! Only 6 available.

Contributions in any amount are most welcome!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign far and wide to help us reach our goal. Thank you so much!
Please join us at Man Base at sunrise on Tuesday of burn week for a healing and meditation ritual ceremony marking the gifting of the Wings of Eos Shrine to Black Rock City.

story:
Hello,

I'm Vitus Shell, a visual artist and professor from Monroe, LA. My artwork is about the community and that is why this project is important to me.

The Community Soup Kitchen has served the community of South Monroe since 1989. After talking with the Salvation Army and finding that they didn't have a feeding program, Lillie "Granny" Goins and her husband, Poppa, started feeding the homeless of downtown Monroe from the trunk of their car. The Soup Kitchen moved into it's current location in 1997. After Granny Goins passed 2007, her daughter, Gladys has keep the vision of her parents alive by feeding the community every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday.

story:
We are asking your support to help produce a 2nd season of Prison Poetry Workshop radio series which will allow us to continue to explore the unheralded art and cultural tradition of prison poetry; this includes sending the series inside our nation's prisons. 

Your support will help produce eight one-hour programs, 12-podcasts, and provide us with the capacity to send the series into over 200 facilities across the country. 

In our first season we engaged thousands of prison poets who are now eagerly waiting for our 2nd season and with your support we'll send powerful art over the airwaves and into their prison cells.

We're invoking the spirit of prison poet Etheridge Knight to help complete the 2nd year. Show us your support for prison poetry by clicking on the t-shirt image below---we'd like to send you the t-shirt it represents as a donation perk--- and by sporting Etheridge's likeness!

Prison Poetry—the poetry of Etheridge Knight and others—is a distinct literary tradition, yet one rooted in larger and more readily recognized American literary traditions. Prison poetry reflects and refracts the geographic, historical, social, and political context that has shaped the U.S. criminal justice system. 


We produced a pilot season of the Prison Poetry Workshop with the support of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA). Now, with your support we'll produce a 2nd season of the series, and organize a deep engagement campaign that goes directly into our nation's prisons. We'll bring new voices to the outside by recording some of our content behind prison walls.

The need for America to hear and recognize the  voices of her prison poets is more urgent now, than ever. The crisis of mass incarceration continues to operate on historic levels, with some 2.4 million people behind bars in the U.S.; another 5 million on probation and parole; and many millions of immediate family members affected by the incarceration of a loved one. We also have a unique opportunity now as the movement against mass incarceration gains strength, as evidenced by the popularity and success of Michelle Alexander’s book,“The New Jim Crow,” to reach out to new audiences.

By spotlighting historical and contemporary prison poets, we break down the barriers between those of us on the inside and those of us on the outside, resisting dehumanizing those behind bars and learning to oppose policies that perpetuate injustice.

In his poem “Cell Song,” prison poet Etheridge Knight asks, “can anything good come out of prison?” An answer is found in the way talented individuals like Knight convert their experiences into narratives of renewal. Their poetry helps us see our society from a new vantage point, and opens us up the possibility of change.

We have an amazing production team, dedicated volunteers (both on the inside and outside), and many prison poets from our first season, to help us create our new season. With your support, we'll launch an amazing the Prison Poetry Workshop sequel.

Regards,

Rend Smith and Nick Szuberla (producers)

story:
Kurzbeschreibung

 

Unterstützer finanzieren Ideen, die ihnen gefallen und von Personen, denen sie vertrauen. Hier sind einige Punkte, die du in diesem Abschnitt beachten solltest:

 
     
  • Stelle dich und deinen Hintergrund vor.
    •  
  • Beschreibe deine Kampagne kurz und knackig und erkläre, weshalb sie so wichtig für dich ist.
    •  
  • Beschreibe, wobei die Unterstützer dir helfen werden.
    •  
 

Denke daran, dich kurz zu halten. Stelle dir folgende Fragen: Wenn jemand hier aufhört zu lesen, wäre derjenige dann bereit, Geld zu geben?

 
 
 

Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst

 

Gehe etwas mehr ins Detail für alle Besucher, die daran interessiert sind:

 
     
  • Erkläre, wie viel Geld du benötigst und wofür es eingesetzt wird. Bleib transparent und sag konkret, worum es geht – die Leute sollen dir und deiner Kampagne vertrauen.
    •  
  • Erzähle den Leuten von deinen einzigartigen Perks. Mach sie neugierig!
    •  
  • Erkläre, wohin die Finanzmittel gehen, wenn du das Funding-Ziel nicht erreichst.
    •  
 
 
 

Die Folgen

 

Verrate mehr über deine Kampagne und lass die Leute wissen, was sie mit ihrem Beitrag bewirken:

 
     
  • Erkläre, warum dein Projekt für den Unterstützer und die Welt wichtig ist.
    •  
  • Erwähne ähnliche Projekte, mit denen du in der Vergangenheit erfolgreich warst (falls es welche gibt).
    •  
  • Mach das Projekt für die Leute real und baue Vertrauen auf.
    •  
 
 
 

Risiken & Herausforderungen

 

Die Leute schätzen deine Transparenz. Bleib offen und stich aus der Masse heraus, indem du ohne Umschweife von den Risiken und Hindernissen erzählst, die dir auf dem Weg zum Erreichen deines Ziels begegnen.

 
     
  • Informiere deine Unterstützer, warum gerade du diese Hürden überwinden wirst.
    •  
  • Beschreibe, wie du diese Herausforderungen bewältigen möchtest.
    •  
 
 
 

Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

 

Manche können einfach keinen Beitrag leisten, das heißt aber nicht, dass sie nicht helfen können:

 
     
  • Bitte darum, dass man über deine Kampagne spricht und sie so bekannt macht.
    •  
  • Erinnere daran, das Tool von Indiegogo dafür zu nutzen!
    •  
 
 

Das war es auch schon.
story_txt: Kurzbeschreibung Unterstützer finanzieren Ideen, die ihnen gefallen und von Personen, denen sie vertrauen. Hier sind einige Punkte, die du in diesem Abschnitt beachten solltest:  Stelle dich und deinen Hintergrund vor. Beschreibe deine Kampagne kurz und knackig und erkläre, weshalb sie so wichtig für dich ist. Beschreibe, wobei die Unterstützer dir helfen werden.  Denke daran, dich kurz zu halten. Stelle dir folgende Fragen: Wenn jemand hier aufhört zu lesen, wäre derjenige dann bereit, Geld zu geben?   Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst Gehe etwas mehr ins Detail für alle Besucher, die daran interessiert sind:  Erkläre, wie viel Geld du benötigst und wofür es eingesetzt wird. Bleib transparent und sag konkret, worum es geht – die Leute sollen dir und deiner Kampagne vertrauen.  Erzähle den Leuten von deinen einzigartigen Perks. Mach sie neugierig! Erkläre, wohin die Finanzmittel gehen, wenn du das Funding-Ziel nicht erreichst.    Die Folgen Verrate mehr über deine Kampagne und lass die Leute wissen, was sie mit ihrem Beitrag bewirken:  Erkläre, warum dein Projekt für den Unterstützer und die Welt wichtig ist. Erwähne ähnliche Projekte, mit denen du in der Vergangenheit erfolgreich warst (falls es welche gibt). Mach das Projekt für die Leute real und baue Vertrauen auf.    Risiken & Herausforderungen  Die Leute schätzen deine Transparenz. Bleib offen und stich aus der Masse heraus, indem du ohne Umschweife von den Risiken und Hindernissen erzählst, die dir auf dem Weg zum Erreichen deines Ziels begegnen.  Informiere deine Unterstützer, warum gerade du diese Hürden überwinden wirst. Beschreibe, wie du diese Herausforderungen bewältigen möchtest.    Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann Manche können einfach keinen Beitrag leisten, das heißt aber nicht, dass sie nicht helfen können:  Bitte darum, dass man über deine Kampagne spricht und sie so bekannt macht. Erinnere daran, das Tool von Indiegogo dafür zu nutzen!   Das war es auch schon.

story:
"Postcards from Scotland" a timelapse series.

First of all, the project I'm working on is a timelapse series about the gorgeous scenery of Scotland. But there's a lot more to this one! Below I'll explain the bigger picture and the video above will give you a short preview of some initial test shots. Please do watch the video in higher quality setting such as HD or 4K.

You give some, we all give some...

Being a very passionate photographer and person in general I am really excited about starting this project! For a long time I have been thinking about a way to give back to the world instead of just asking for help for my personal goal.

This is the plan I came up with and why I am convinced we can make some magic happen... Follow along and let me explain!

This is where my plan becomes our goal...

Instead of the usual approach of handing out perks to funders I decided to try something else!

Funding the total project will make it easier for me to complete this series of short films but it will do more than just that!

Like I said before, I want to give something back! A present with all of our names written all over it! 

I hereby pledge to donate all generated income from these films to a cause we can agree on! Also, in case this project would get funded more than 100%, that funding will go towards the same cause(s)!

The way I would like to set this up is to give every funder a voice. Later on in the campaign I will set up a voting/poll system where every one of you can give your own personal opinion of where you think potential income should go and why. 

This way, I get to work on a great project which we will all get to enjoy but we will also work together for a greater goal!

The impact we could have?

Basically... The Sky is the limit!

The better I can produce my films and the bigger we can make our group, the more people or causes could benefit from this! This one is all about spreading the word and proving we live in a world where people care about each other.

Personally, I am not looking to benefit from this but just aiming to get this part of my investment funded in an original way. I will be blogging about this project as I go and keep every one of you up to date on where it's going and how we're doing.

The funds will only go towards technical support and the logistical aspect of the series. After production, the footage will not generate any income at all for myself. It will all be available for sale through me or any of the funders taking part in this campaign. Once again, the more people this reaches, the greater things we can do!

Feel free to share this campaign and later footage in any shape or form! You can always contact me personally with specific questions and/or if you wish to discuss other forms of funding.

You can share all of this information through the social media share buttons which indiegogo provides and/or follow along on my personal pages through one of the links below.

www.jangoris.com

https://www.facebook.com/jangorisphotography

I truly hope we can do great things together and prove the world is a wonderful place!
Thank you all for reading, sharing and contributing!

Jan

story:
Hello. I'm Daniel Trudeau. I am a single father and DIY musician from The Sierra Nevada Foothills in California. I have an insanely imaginative and brilliant 4 year old daughter named Juniper Arroak Trudeau who believes that her imaginary friend "MiMi" is lost somewhere in Germany. 

While "MiMi" has been lost in Germany Juniper and I have been living out our lives wondering how in the world we will ever be able to see her again. Apparently MiMi went missing about a year ago.

I've decided to start this IndieGogo campaign to -

1. Purchase my daughter a plane ticket to Germany (accompanied by myself of course)

2. Purchase my daughter's Passport

Funding this will not only get my daughter and myself over to Germany to finally meet MiMi but it will also make it possible for my daughter to tour with her father somewhere over seas. 

*In the last 4 years I've toured Japan, South Korea and the United Kingdom with my band but alas, I could never bring my daughter Juniper along with me.

Funding this project will culminate in 3 (or more) things - 

1. I can share the experience of international travel with my child.

2. Juniper can finally construct the image of MiMi (her imaginary friend) based on her experience of the vacation/tour.

3. I can tour Europe with the peace of mind that I didn't leave my daughter behind.

In closing I just want to state that the importance of funding this project is in the fact that we as parents do not support our children's imaginations to our utmost effort. I want Juniper to know that she can do whatever she wants. I want her to know that there are no limitations to her imagination.

I've provided links below to my music and to a soundcloud page that consists of music reviews done by Juniper and myself over the last couple of years - 

my band's name is Pregnant - 

https://soundcloud.com/danielispregnant

http://vimeo.com/84428711

Here is my our (Juniper and I) Music Review Stream-

https://soundcloud.com/10-years-ahead-of-you

story:
Short Summary

LOVE is excited to announce we are shifting to neighborhood-based programming. LOVE plans to move to northern Manhattan and focus on young people who live in one of Manhattan's most impoverished areas.  We will also continue to work with youth who have had contact with the juvenile justice system.

We need your help so that we can start up programs in our new neighborhood in January. Our goal is to raise $20,000 by December 15th.

LOVE U.S.’s mission is to enable youth who have been affected by violence to create positive change in their lives and become leaders among their peers and in their communities.

We do this by providing safe settings, media arts training, social and emotional learning, and leadership development opportunities. Youth emerge from LOVE U.S. committed to carrying forward messages of non-violence, and ready to engage more fully in the world around them.

LOVE U.S. offers:
  • School-based afterschool programs
  • Programs for youth-mandated through the criminal justice system 
  • Youth leadership programs

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous donation will help us keep or secure adequate workshop space, purchase program materials, and assist us with compensating our dedicated staff. All of the donations help us to create a safe space for youth who need it most!

You will receive a number of amazing gifts.  Please see our listing of "perks". 

The Impact

The impact of LOVE U.S. on our youth is impressive:

LOVE U.S. is a media arts based violence prevention program that has helped hundreds of youth in New York City for over 12 years!

  • LOVE U.S.’s youth say that this program has saved their lives, means everything to them and is a place they feel safe and at home
  • 90% of LOVE U.S. youth leaders have graduated high school, and gone to college
  • 100% of our Youth Leaders felt they had developed communication and leadership skills since joining LOVE U.S.
  • 77% of all the youth we serve demonstrated improvement in the areas of academic self-efficacy, self management, positive identity, social skills, contribution, and social capital
  • 100% of Leaders agreed they had developed healthy coping and violence-prevention skills since joining a LOVE U.S. program

Other Ways You Can Help

Unable to make a donation in the amounts listed?  Please go to our website (http://newyork.leaveoutviolence.org/) and make a donation in any amount that you are able.  Please share this page and the mission of LOVE New York with your friends and follow us on Facebook.

story:
$1 Movement

Everything starts with $1: Giving shouldn't come with hidden costs, so we came up with a movement that is affordable and accessible to all. 

Our $1 Movement is part of a non-profit foundation, Make Them Thrive, that musters donations and volunteer help to provide support to families of prisoners by uniting them together each year during their time of incarceration. Nationally, 7.3 million children have at least one parent in jail or prison. Sadly, 70 percent of these kids are doomed to follow in the same footsteps as their parents becoming imprisoned at some point in their lives.

$1 Movement Around The World: Join Others Like You Whose Mission Is To Change Lives.

There are many ways you can make a difference by donating $1 and joining our movement. Share this on your social media with your friends. Be a part of our global community. Help us to create sustainable and responsible programs for communities in need. Every time you donate $1, a person in need is helped. 

Donate your $1 and help spread the LOVE

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need you to share your LOVE by donating just $1.
  • Each $1 donated will help kids visit their parents in prison.
  • By shopping at our online shop, you will receive 10% off your first order.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to tell your friends all about it.

Lets spread the LOVE and make them THRIVE.

www.makethemthrive.org

story:
Imagine your favourite café: that cosy spot where you like hanging out with friends in the evening, or having a morning coffee break, or whatever.

Now spice it up with cool music, beautiful decorations, comfy cushions, healthy food and drinks... anything you may need to feel relaxed and happy. Put it on four wheels... and you have the VegArt Van!

From the wish to make people feeling good, the Veg Art Van concept was conceived.

My name is Jane and I'm a life-enthusiastic person. At the age of 18 I quit my comfort zone (which didn't really make me comfortable!) and started traveling around Europe. It's been two years since then and my passion about diversity, discovery and beauty has done nothing but grow. What I mostly love is to challenge myself and others to do better and be better.

Have you ever dreamed of traveling long-term across unexplored lands and cultures?

Have you ever dreamed of meeting creative, positive and empowering people?

Have you ever dreamed of seeing others smile and thank you at a yummy dish you've made with love and dedication for them?

Have you ever dreamed of seeing others close their eyes and dance at the sound of your music and voice?

This is what the Veg Art Van dreams about.

Can you feel the excitement of such a great project?

Well, with your help you can make it real and even be a part of it!

The Veg Art Van aims at teaching people to enjoy life, to be authentic and caring about themselves and surrounding environment. Giving food for thoughts, food for body and food for soul.

Hands-on: what your contribution will be used for?

The current goal has been set on a very optimistic planning, but your help will be very much appreciated even if only some of the following steps will be achieved:

  1. Approximately 6ooo € will be needed to purchase a second-hand campervan. Why buy a new one if new life can be given to old good vans too? Plus, the charme of vintage is irreplaceable!

  2. Around 4000 € will be required to make the necessary interior, exterior and mechanical restoration. A structural personalisation is essential to make up a unique concept as the VegArt Van is! That includes new insulation, new furnitures equipment, cooking tools, a sound system, detachable equipments for an outdoor siesta area for guests, and many more little details.

  3. The next 2000 € are required to accomplish all the bureaucratic procedures (!!) such as getting authorizations to food handling, to offer a service on the public ground, to insure the van, and so on.

  4. The remaining 3000€ will be all spent for marketing and merchandising... of course this last one is not essential to the launch of the project, however it would make it extremely easier. The more you contribute, the more we're going to give resonation to this project!

Any kind of help from you will be truly appreciated.

If you don't want to make a donation, or you can't afford it, still there's a very quick and cheap way you can support the VegArt Van Project: spread the word!

Share this page and the video on your socials, talk about it to as many people as you can! 

And remember that even making a little donation we'll thank you with nice perks!

Please notice that some perks, especially higher ones, will require longer time to be available, as they depend completely on the success of the campaign and the effective launch of the project. Stay tuned for every update and contact Jane if you have any doubt and question about perks (shipping, sizes, etc) or about the project itself.
And check out the website and the facebook page!

Thank you very much for your engagement.

story:
In the year 2015, the Cyprus’ Ministry of Culture launched a special program in order to support artistic events. The program was imaginatively called “Culture”.

  Everybody knows that culture, not only as a ministry, but as a ministry’s program as well, can easily be turned into a really weird situation.

  However, the fact that the state wanted to help artists in their various ventures, especially during an era of financial crisis, was a reason for us to feel encouraged.

  A title, or the epilogue, for all these, could be “Great Expectations”, but let’s carry on with our story.

  Those days, we had already scheduled an event called “Street Art Square”. It would happen in Paphos, at a central parking lot of our town, where we would create some street artwork, and transform the place into an open art gallery.

  The participants wouldn’t be just local artists, but, also, artists from other cities of Cyprus, and from all over the world. This, as one can understand, raised the financial cost of the event, but we decided that it was worth it, so we proceeded.

  We had our faith not only to God, and various universal conspiracies, but to state’s help as well. So, we wrote a letter, on behalf of Paphos’ Letters & Arts Association, asking our event to be considered as part of that special program called “Culture”. 

  Our main thought was: Why the hell not?

  So, we asked for sponsorship, a good old habit that was introduced by ancient Greeks, and became extremely famous during eras like the Renaissance.

  One can think, again, the “Great Expectations” factor – but hold your horses.

  Since we are old friends with bureaucracy, our application form arrived at the Ministry of Culture long before the expiration date; yet, we made a phone call to them, just in case something had gone wrong.

  The phone was answered by the civil servant responsible for the applications regarding painting etc. Let’s call this servant Pete. It’s such a nice name.

  So, Pete let us know that he had received our application form, and that it was properly filled. He also said that our proposal was up to the Ministry’s demands.

  Most importantly, Pete announced that the Ministry’s Cultural Services would answer the soonest possible, probably until the end of March, and, in any case, before our event – which was scheduled for April 17th and 18th.

  Unfortunately, it seems that bureaucracy had other plans, so no one bothered enough to send us an answer. That’s OK: shit happens.  


  At that point, we decided to become Pete’s best friends, and we called him in order to say so. Pete was so flattered that promised to evaluate our application right after Easter holidays.

  We felt sure that a guy like Pete wouldn’t break such an important promise, and that’s why we proceed with our event, which was warmly welcomed by the people of Paphos.

  To this day, we believe that the Ministry was deeply touched, and excited by the success of our venture, but the servants there must be fans of suspense, something that explains the fact that April, and May passed without a single sign, or proof of life.

  Don’t worry, though: both the Ministry, and Pete, are alive and kicking.

  However, we couldn’t be sure about that, so we made some phone calls, in order to know that there hadn’t been any deadly accidents in the Ministry.

  To be specific, we were so worried, that we spoke 24 times, on the phone, with Pete, during a time of 4 months – that’s more than we have spoken to the phone with most (if not all) of the women that walked through our adventurous life.

  Perhaps we should mention the unanswered phone calls as well, but who’s counting?

  During the 24 conversations that Pete was kind enough to have with us, he apologised for the delay, and he kept assuring us that everything’s fine, and that soon enough we would receive the final, and formal answer of the Ministry.

  Obviously, without the suspense factor, our life would be unbearably boring.

  In July, after Pete analysed the reasons of the delay, he made a striking revelation: he said that the Ministry was capable of covering the 65-70% of our expenses, and he added that he was talking informally.

  Pete emphasized at the word INFORMALLY, and he also emphasized at the word SURE – meaning that he was sure that the Ministry was capable of covering those expenses.

  So, according to the noble science of maths, the Ministry would offer approximately 10.000 Euros, since the Street Art Square’s entire cost had reached up to 17.000 Euros.

  Pete, our loyal phone friend, explained us the exact way of transferring the money into the bank account, and he constantly reassured us that everything would be taken care of really soon, especially because the event had already taken place.

  So, every time we were saying goodbye to him, he was promising that he would call us back himself, “on Friday”, to let us know the final details.

  Pete, as we later discovered, is the accurate type of guy, and that’s why he was never clear about which Friday he meant: it could be the final Friday because the End of Days, and the Apocalypse.

  That’s what the saying “ThankGodit’sFriday” is all about.

  After a series of such blessed Fridays, we reached the first days of August, when Pete was getting ready to go on vacations. Then, he shared with us his honest hope that everything would be over before his vacation.

  Obviously, hope dies when everyone goes on vacation, leaving hope locked inside their office, bound to starve to death.

  Since then, Pete hasn’t answered our phone calls, and no one knows why; he may was too suntanned during summer, or he decided that he didn’t love us any more – everything’s possible.

  On September 6th, in the year 2015, Paphos’ Letters & Arts Association received an answer from the Ministry’s Cultural Services, which announced that, after all, our application was rejected, and no money would be given for our event.

  That’s happy ending, but we are not over yet.




  The answer, in Ministry’s exact words, was that: “The venture proposed activates a wide range of artistic force, and disperse Art in Citizen’s everyday life. However, the lack of a clearly stated thinking weakens the initial intention”.

  We know that good intentions lead straight to Hell. The weakened ones lead us to the nearest drugstore, for wine, and cigarettes, and that’s if we’re lucky.

  Obviously, culture is a clear stated thinking, just like William Blake’s poems.

  In this heartbreaking marathon, our application form won the 37th place, with 79.75 points; yet, we are not sure about the evaluation scale: it was the Richter one, the Celsius, or the Fahrenheit?

  We’ll never know, and that’s suspense for you, guys, as well as for us.

  The sponsorship was given only for the first 24 places of the marathon, since the tanks of money went empty after that. That’s understandable: we feel empty after that, as well.

  Let us say, just for the sake of future history, that the Organisation of PAPHOS2017 agreed to cover the 15-20% of the expenses for the Street Art Square, which had taken place with the support of Paphos’ Letters & Arts Association.

  At this moment, after covering a part of the 17.000 Euros which is the entire cost of our event, it is really urgent for us to find the amount of 5.500 Euros.

  These 5.500 Euros is the money we spent for the materials, the documentary, the photo-shooting of the event, the plane tickets, and the meals for the foreign artists, as well as the various other means needed for our venture (lights, stage, sound system for the concert, promo material like flyers etc). needless to say that all artists worked with out any compensation, all in a voluntary basis.

  The curator of the Street Art Square, Y.S. is currently indebted to the artists for their tickets, and to the various services that helped us throughout the venture.

  This Crowdfunding effort is our best chance to pay our debt, and that is why we are offering original works of art to all of you that are interested in participating, by trusting us any amount of money you want, and are able to give.

  If we manage to gather more money than the 5.500 Euros of our debt, we are going to set up a similar artistic venture during September 2016.

  If you allow us, and help us do this, we will definitely send a NOT clearly stated invitation to our loyal friend Pete, and the Cyprus’ Ministry of Culture, just for the good old days’ sake.

  Needless to say that this invitation will be signed by our true sponsors: You. the names of all the contributors will be added to the background of the next poster

  We sincerely thank you all in advance for your help.
story_txt:
In the year
2015, the Cyprus’ Ministry of Culture launched a special program in order to
support artistic events. The program was imaginatively called “Culture”.
  Everybody knows that culture, not
only as a ministry, but as a ministry’s program as well, can easily be turned
into a really weird situation. 
  However, the fact that the state
wanted to help artists in their various ventures, especially during an era of financial
crisis, was a reason for us to feel encouraged.
  A title, or the epilogue, for all
these, could be “Great Expectations”, but let’s carry on with our story. 
  Those days, we had already scheduled
an event called “Street Art Square”. It would happen in Paphos, at a central
parking lot of our town, where we would create some street artwork, and
transform the place into an open art gallery.



  The participants wouldn’t be just
local artists, but, also, artists from other cities of Cyprus, and from all over
the world. This, as one can understand, raised the financial cost of the event,
but we decided that it was worth it, so we proceeded.
  We had our faith not only to God,
and various universal conspiracies, but to state’s help as well. So, we wrote a
letter, on behalf of Paphos’ Letters & Arts Association, asking our event
to be considered as part of that special program called “Culture”.  
  Our main thought was: Why the hell
not?
  So, we asked for sponsorship, a good
old habit that was introduced by ancient Greeks, and became extremely famous
during eras like the Renaissance. 
  One can think, again, the “Great
Expectations” factor – but hold your horses. 
  Since we are old friends with
bureaucracy, our application form arrived at the Ministry of Culture long
before the expiration date; yet, we made a phone call to them, just in case
something had gone wrong. 
  The phone was answered by the civil
servant responsible for the applications regarding painting etc. Let’s call this
servant Pete. It’s such a nice name. 
  So, Pete let us know that he had
received our application form, and that it was properly filled. He also said that
our proposal was up to the Ministry’s demands. 
  Most importantly, Pete announced
that the Ministry’s Cultural Services would answer the soonest possible,
probably until the end of March, and, in any case, before our event – which was
scheduled for April 17th and 18th.
  Unfortunately, it seems that
bureaucracy had other plans, so no one bothered enough to send us an answer.
That’s OK: shit happens.  



  At that point, we decided to become
Pete’s best friends, and we called him in order to say so. Pete was so
flattered that promised to evaluate our application right after Easter
holidays. 
  We felt sure that a guy like Pete
wouldn’t break such an important promise, and that’s why we proceed with our
event, which was warmly welcomed by the people of Paphos. 
  To this day, we believe that the
Ministry was deeply touched, and excited by the success of our venture, but the
servants there must be fans of suspense, something that explains the fact that
April, and May passed without a single sign, or proof of life. 
  Don’t worry, though: both the
Ministry, and Pete, are alive and kicking. 
  However, we couldn’t be sure about
that, so we made some phone calls, in order to know that there hadn’t been any deadly
accidents in the Ministry. 
  To be specific, we were so worried,
that we spoke 24 times, on the phone, with Pete, during a time of 4 months –
that’s more than we have spoken to the phone with most (if not all) of the
women that walked through our adventurous life. 


  Perhaps we should mention the
unanswered phone calls as well, but who’s counting?
  During the 24 conversations that
Pete was kind enough to have with us, he apologised for the delay, and he kept
assuring us that everything’s fine, and that soon enough we would receive the
final, and formal answer of the Ministry. 
  Obviously, without the suspense
factor, our life would be unbearably boring.
  In July, after Pete analysed the
reasons of the delay, he made a striking revelation: he said that the Ministry
was capable of covering the 65-70% of our expenses, and he added that he was
talking informally. 
  Pete emphasized at the word INFORMALLY,
and he also emphasized at the word SURE – meaning that he was sure that the
Ministry was capable of covering those expenses. 
  So, according to the noble science
of maths, the Ministry would offer approximately 10.000 Euros, since the Street
Art Square’s entire cost had reached up to 17.000 Euros. 
  Pete, our loyal phone friend,
explained us the exact way of transferring the money into the bank account, and
he constantly reassured us that everything would be taken care of really soon,
especially because the event had already taken place. 
  So, every time we were saying
goodbye to him, he was promising that he would call us back himself, “on
Friday”, to let us know the final details. 
  Pete, as we later discovered, is the
accurate type of guy, and that’s why he was never clear about which Friday he
meant: it could be the final Friday because the End of Days, and the
Apocalypse. 
  That’s what the saying “ThankGodit’sFriday”
is all about.
  After a series of such blessed
Fridays, we reached the first days of August, when Pete was getting ready to go
on vacations. Then, he shared with us his honest hope that everything would be
over before his vacation. 
  Obviously, hope dies when everyone
goes on vacation, leaving hope locked inside their office, bound to starve to
death.
  Since then, Pete hasn’t answered our
phone calls, and no one knows why; he may was too suntanned during summer, or
he decided that he didn’t love us any more – everything’s possible. 
  On September 6th, in the year 2015, Paphos’
Letters & Arts Association received an answer from the Ministry’s Cultural
Services, which announced that, after all, our application was rejected, and no
money would be given for our event. 
  That’s happy ending, but we are not
over yet. 



  The answer, in Ministry’s exact words, was that: “The
venture proposed activates a wide range of artistic force, and disperse Art in
Citizen’s everyday life. However, the lack of a clearly stated thinking weakens
the initial intention”.

and cigarettes, and that’s if we’re lucky.

thinking, just like William Blake’s poems.

  Let us say, just for the sake of
future history, that the Organisation of PAPHOS2017 agreed to cover the 15-20%
of the expenses for the Street Art Square, which had taken place with the
support of Paphos’ Letters & Arts Association.
  At this moment, after covering a
part of the 17.000 Euros which is the entire cost of our event, it is really
urgent for us to find the amount of 5.500 Euros. 
  These 5.500 Euros is the money we
spent for the materials, the documentary, the photo-shooting of the event, the
plane tickets, and the meals for the foreign artists, as well as the various
other means needed for our venture (lights, stage, sound system for the
concert, promo material like flyers etc). needless to say that all artists worked with out any compensation, all in a voluntary basis.
  The curator of the Street Art
Square, Y.S. is currently indebted to the artists for their tickets, and to the
various services that helped us throughout the venture.
  This Crowdfunding effort is our
best chance to pay our debt, and that is why we are offering original works of
art to all of you that are interested in participating, by trusting us any
amount of money you want, and are able to give. 
  If we manage to gather more money
than the 5.500 Euros of our debt, we are going to set up a similar artistic
venture during September 2016. 
  If you allow us, and help us do
this, we will definitely send a NOT clearly stated invitation to our loyal friend Pete, and the Cyprus’
Ministry of Culture, just for the good old days’ sake.
  Needless to say that this invitation
will be signed by our true sponsors: You. the names of all the contributors will be added to the background of the next poster
  We sincerely thank you all in
advance for your help.

story:
I am an emerging artist working to build a career as an artist. I feel very enthusiastic about the possibilities in the art field, ceramic art in particular. I am looking to start the new phase of my artistic career with my own home studio. I have been fortunate enough to have facilities and equipment available to me for over ten years. Now it is time for me to get out on my own and build my own studio!

To do this I will need your help!  The money earned from this Indiegogo campaign  will be used build my studio and ceramics business.  I will purchase tools, supplies and equipment for my home studio. I will first be making a bulk purchase of porcelain, get a small kiln to fire the work, and other materials and furniture for my studio. 

I have some great perks available if you would like to participate in my fundraising efforts. I will be making the orders as they come and as i get my studio set up. It can take a while to get enough work to fill a kiln , so it could take 1-3 months to get your orders. Orders received before the end of this 60 day Indiegogo campaign will definitely arrive in by the first week of December.


About my work:

My ceramic work shows a portrait of the city in which I live. I make functional porcelain pieces illustrated with drawings and observations of the local environment. the illustrations bring attention to the beauty of the urban landscape, and show details of daily life that can often be overlooked.The elements depicted are representative and unique to the local urban landscape, a local can view the illustrations and recognize their city in the landmarks and buildings, yet the images are also vague enough that the non-local can also to relate to the imagery.

The muted color palate gives the work an unimposing quality, paired with clean lines and the contrast of glazed and unglazed surfaces the work has a sharp quality to hold the viewers attention. Function brings the viewer in contact with the illustrations giving them a chance to investigate the form, surface, and drawings. The viewer can identify with the scene and create their own narrative and relationship to the illustrations.


About me:

I have always shrived to bring art into every part of my life. Born into a family of artists, my mother a painter, and my grandparents have worked in ceramics for over 50 years. I place great importance on having art objects in one's life, and have always known I would find a career in the art field. Beginning with small projects in my grandparent's studio I have always had an affinity for ceramics. The influence of the many instructors I have had over the years has given me a diverse ceramic education and helped me to develop a unique voice and style. Whether enrolled as a student or out of school I have remained committed to my participation in the artistic community. I have also had opportunities to show my work, in both solo and group exhibitions.

My formal pursuit of ceramics began at Southern Oregon University from 2003-2008. In the summer of 2006 I apprenticed under the French potter Jean Nicolas Gerard in Valensole, France. I studied as a Post-baccalaureate student at University of Florida from 2010-2011. In 2011 I enrolled in the Masters of Fine Arts program in ceramics at Louisiana State University receiving my degree in 2014. After completing graduate school at LSU, I was awarded Fogleberg Fellowship at Northern Clay Center her in Minneapolis. The fellowship at Northern Clay Center has given me opportunity to gain valuable experience teaching adult and youth classes. Northern Clay Center has given me a lively and creative environment where I can focus on developing my body of work while engaging with the artistic community.

The fellowship period at Northern Clay Center is coming to a close in September and i am ready to get out on my own with a home studio, and all everything that goes with it!

story:
Hi, my name is Jen Krava and I'm collaborating with Survivor Theatre Project and In Divine Company to develop a multimedia workshop that seeks to expose and transform the system of structural and institutional oppression that reinforces sexual harassment. This will be done by incorporating wearable sculptures I have designed as performance and healing tools during the workshop.  Our goal is to hold a concluding exhibit and performance in Boston this December and we need your support to make this all happen!

Combining Survivor Theatre Project's work organizing healing theatre workshops and performances for survivors of sexual violence, In Divine Company's exploration of story-telling as a performance tool for social justice activism, and my experience as a designer, we aim to break the illusions that localize and personalize instances of violence. Instead, we will reveal the systemic oppressions that propagate these instances and offer ideas with which to dismantle the victim blaming myths in our toxic culture.

The workshops will be rooted in movement games that allow participants to create empowering narratives. Through our workshops, we aim to fracture the cycle of violence that is engendered in instances of sexual harassment and community policing. We will do so by breaking the myth that occurrences are attributed to the perpetrator/s and victim/s’ race, class, gender, and sexual orientation and by providing examples of community-centered solutions that halt sexual harassment, and are developed by workshop participants.

The wearable sculptures will provide an opportunity for the wearer to understand and convey the complex interactions between themselves and these systems of oppression through performance. These multimedia story-telling workshops spark much needed dialogue on negotiating the personal in the public. They will utilize the wearable sculptures to give physical form to otherwise invisible psychological pressures imparted by normalized systemic violence.

We will conduct and document three workshops with members of the public who are community leaders. In December, we will hold an exhibit of the documentation in conjunction with an abridged performance demonstrating the movement games and narratives developed in the workshops. As part of the exhibit we will facilitate a public discussion on the community workshop model as a tool in the battle against systemic sexual harassment.

We have a small bit of support from the Somerville Arts Council, but for this project to be a success, we need your help! Your support will ensure fair compensation to everyone involved; the performers, administrators, and workshop participants, allow us to rent space for the workshop and performance, and purchase the materials that we need. Your contribution will help the workshops, rehearsals, performance, and exhibit come to fruition in our continued struggle to dismantle the oppressive systems and structures which continue to plague our communities.

Every bit will help, so please give what you can. Thank you for your support!

What We Need & What You Get

We need a minimum of $2000 to pay the performers, administrators, and workshop participants a fair wage for their time and effort.  These funds will also help to pay the rental rates for the concluding performance and exhibit, which will likely be held at the Armory in Somerville.  

If you donate, you'll get a behind the scenes update, special momento, or front row seat to the workshop and exhibit!  Check out all of our special perks; there's something for every budget!  

If we don't reach our goal, we will stretch what we do make as thin as possible.  This means below minimum wage payment for performers, administrators, and workshop participants.  It also means we will ask for donations on the evening of the performance and exhibit.  We want to avoid this, so our focus can be on the important events of the night!

The Impact

Acts of sexual violence and harassment are interconnected, but they are all attacks on personal space, which reflects our identity and the way in which we perform that identity. These acts of sexual violence and harassment threaten our sense of personal space, thus challenging our personal identities and values. By exploring how our movements effect others, we can begin to effect all of the acts of sexual violence on the scope.

Your donation helps us spark much needed conversation about personal space within the public while giving physical form to otherwise invisible emotional and psychological thresholds of participants. Engaging communities in the investigation of identity choreographies performed in public spaces helps to expose practices of violence ingrained within the cultural fabric, and prompts new options for reweaving the fabric and inculcating social harmony.

Other Ways You Can Help

Yes, your monetary donation is important for this project, but talking about these issues is imperative.  Please talk about these issues with one another in caring, understanding ways.  As my dad said to me every day, "just be nice to everybody".  There's really nothing to lose in that.

You can also share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and whatever other social media you subscribe to.  Please help us spread the word, and come see us in December! 

More About Us

Survivor Theatre Project is a free theatre arts experience that brings creativity, community and performance to survivors of sexual violence in Boston. STP was created in response to an urgent need for survivors of sexual violence to bring their voices to the public discourse. The work is guided by an anti-oppression framework to allow multiple, complex identities and experiences looking for expression, exploration, recognition and healing, within the context of sexual violence.

In Divine Company is a Boston based, activist dance company with a contemporary temple dance aesthetic. IDC is a movement experiment exploring the diasporic identity by addressing social justice issues of caste, gender, sexuality, and body politic from a decidedly contemporary lens. 

I have been involved on project teams analyzing sexual assault policies, conceptualized an app for women who would like a virtual support network when alone in public space, and created a public mapping system that exposes existent community resources.

story:
Who am I and what I do!

Hi my name is Becky Alarie. I am currently working in Dunham, Québec, Canada with a non-profit organization called Youth With A Mission. I am part of a team of three pioneering a film company, called Productions Trois Flèches. Our objective is to make movies that will impact our society positively and to be a support to the film community, such as other filmmakers and workers in the film industry. To do so, I find it important to grow in my knowledge and experience in film. Which is why I am currently in Brisbane Australia, where I just started the School of Digital Filmmaking (SDF) with Youth WIth A Mission Brisbane. During these next three intensive months, I will be learning all I need to know to be able to work in the film industry. I will have classes on storytelling, camera work, lighting, sound, worldview, how to stay true to my values in this industry, etc. I will also have the amazing opportunity to write, produce, direct and edit my own shot film, all while learning about these things. My team and I are also planning on starting the SDF and SAS (School of Acting for the Screen, which runs alongside the SDF) in April 2016 in Québec. 


I need your help!

I can't say thank you enough to all the people who helped me get here. So many people have blessed me financially to help me buy my plane ticket to get to Australia. I was so moved that people believed in me and in my projects.
I am still need about $4,000 AUD for my tuition and about $500 AUD for the cost of my shot film and for different expenses I will have here in Australia. 
Any amount helps, no amount is too small.

If you wish to contact me or receive my newsletter, please let me know on Facebook or by Email.

En Francais/ In French

    Qui suis-je et ce que je fais!

    Salut mon nom est Becky Alarie. Je travaille actuellement à Dunham au Québec, Canada avec un organisme à but non lucratif nomme Youth With A Mission (Jeunesse en Mission). Je fais partie d'une équipe de trois qui commence une compagnie de film, appelé Productions Trois Flèches. Notre objectif est de faire des films qui auront un impact positif sur notre société, ainsi que d'être un soutien à la communaute de cineastes au Quebec. Pour ce faire, je trouve important de grandir dans ma connaissance et mon expérience en cinema. Ce qui explique pourquoi je suis actuellement à Brisbane en Australie, où je viens de commencer l'école de cinéma numérique (School of Digital Filmmaking) avec Jeunesse en Mission Brisbane. Au cours de ces trois prochains mois intensifs, je vais avoir des cours sur tout ce que je dois connaître pour être en mesure de travailler dans l'industrie du cinema. Par exemple, je vais avoir des classes sur la construction d'une histoire, sur la caméra, l'éclairage, le son, sur comment rester fidèle à mes valeurs et integre dans cette industrie, etc. Je vais aussi avoir la chance d'écrire, produire, réaliser et monter mon propre court metrage lors de l'ecole.

    Mon équipe et moi prévoyons également  démarrager les ecoles de film et d'acting (SDF et SAS) en Avril 2016 au Québec.
    Je suis enormement reconnaissante envers ceux qui m'ont aider jusqu'ici. C'est grace a vous, que je reussi a faire ce que je fais.

    J'ai encore besoin de $4,000 afin de payer tout mes frais de scolarité et environ $500 pour le coût de mon film et pour différentes dépenses que je vais avoir ici en Australie.Tout montant aide, aucun montant est trop petit.

    Si vous souhaitez m'écrire ou obtenir plus de mes nouvelles, vous pouvez me contacter par e-mail ou Facebook.

story_txt:
Who am I and what I do! Hi my name is Becky Alarie. I am currently working in Dunham, Québec, Canada with a non-profit organization called Youth With A Mission. I am part of a team of three pioneering a film company, called Productions Trois Flèches. Our objective is to make movies that will impact our society positively and to be a support to the film community, such as other filmmakers and workers in the film industry. To do so, I find it important to grow in my knowledge and experience in film. Which is why I am currently in Brisbane Australia, where I just started the School of Digital Filmmaking (SDF) with Youth WIth A Mission Brisbane. During these next three intensive months, I will be learning all I need to know to be able to work in the film industry. I will have classes on storytelling, camera work, lighting, sound, worldview, how to stay true to my values in this industry, etc. I will also have the amazing opportunity to write, produce, direct and edit my own shot film, all while learning about these things. My team and I are also planning on starting the SDF and SAS (School of Acting for the Screen, which runs alongside the SDF) in April 2016 in Québec. 
   I need your help!
I can't say thank you enough to all the people who helped me get here. So many people have blessed me financially to help me buy my plane ticket to get to Australia. I was so moved that people believed in me and in my projects.
I am still need about $4,000 AUD for my tuition and about $500 AUD for the cost of my shot film and for different expenses I will have here in Australia. 
Any amount helps, no amount is too small. If you wish to contact me or receive my newsletter, please let me know on Facebook or by Email.

story:
Millions of people declare their love on bridges around the world by attaching padlocks and throwing away the key. This gesture is at once incredibly romantic and but to some destructive, and cities, like Paris, have a very real dilemma that needs a solution. 

As an independent filmmaker, documentarian and President of Los Angeles based Cinterra Pictures, I have long been intrigued with this story.  At Cinterra Pictures I suppose we are to be considered “hopeful romantics” who believe that art may be a bridge to solving this predicament. 

So what to do? 

How can cities, and Paris - the City of Love - in particular provide a method for people to continue this expression without compromising their historical landmarks? What if cities chose to harness this outpouring of love and positivity and create an appropriate venue for this expression?

People have an innate desire for connection – to each other, to the places they visit and to history.  It is no coincidence that in our digital and globalized world, people long for a real, permanent, and physical representations of important moments in their lives.

The moment I watched the latest removal of locks from the Pont des Arts, this idea behind this project was born: to document the story of the lovelocks and provide a solution to this problem with the subsequent goal of preserving history and securing a future for this expression.

The Film:  The documentary will tell the story of the lovelocks, the legend and history behind them and their increasing popularity throughout the world.

The Solution: An art installation created  to provide a venue which will allow people to continue to share and show the world their love through the gesture of the locks, but in a method suitable for this purpose. 

Our romanticism makes us dream that art and creativity will find a way to preserve and continue this new tradition. 

The Film – Love Prolific

Feature Documentary Film

Targeted Budget: $500,000

Used to produce a feature-length documentary film –Love Prolific – the stories behind the Paris Love Locks.

Creating The Film:

The story of the lovelocks and this expression, particularly on the Pont des Arts in Paris, involves millions of people around the world. Much like Life in a Day (2011) we will source video submissions from lovelockers around the world and invite them to share their stories with us for use in the documentary.  The best of these stories will be part of the finished film, while the rest will be made available online as a companion to the film.

The film will also explore the real hardship this activity causes for cities and their officials who are tasked with preserving public spaces and historical sites. We will look at the different ways cities react to this activity and explore the varying opinions about the practice of lovelocking. 

The film will also document our solution to the problem cities face: the creation of the art installation specifically designed to give lovelocks a home.

Sculpture

Targeted Budget $500,000

Used to commission an artist to create an art installation specifically designed for the lovelock tradition.

Creating The Installation:

Lovelockers need permanence. We believe that with some effort we can show government officials that they have an opportunity to participate positively in this activity.  Each time a person affixes a lock to a bridge they are asking for a place to express their sentiments not only for or with a loved one but for the host cities themselves.

We intend to choose an artist who sees the possibility in our vision and one who will create a structure that will be a beautiful solution to the lovelocks conundrum. 

This is a real problem, and we have a real solution that can quite literally impact people from all over the world.

We have chosen flexible funding because there are many possible positive outcomes for this project – even if we do not raise the goal of $1 Million.

We believe that at many levels of funding there are still ways we can make a positive impact. We are passionate about telling this story and finding a solution in some way, so chose not to apply for fixed funding. We don’t believe in “all-or-nothing” and this flexibility will allow for this idea to iterate, and be successful at various funding levels.

$20,000 or less:  Funds will be donated to a notable charity.

$20,001 - $100,000: An effort will be made to buy back locks from the City of Paris, and incorporate our "perk" locks to create an installation that will preserve a piece of the Pont des Arts moment. 

$100,001 - $250,000:  We will produce a short film about the lovelocks while also documenting the creation of the smaller traveling instillation.

$250,001 - $750,000: We will produce a feature length documentary film about the lovelocks, their history and include submitted stories. We will also document the creation of the smaller travelling instillation.  

$750,001 - $999,999: Original budgets will be adjusted to make the best possible film we can and the largest instillation we are able in order to reach the widest audience possible. 

Are You a Love Locker?- Are you, or do you know someone who put a lock on the Pont des Arts? If everyone of the estimated one million or more people who declared their love to the world donated just $1 we would be funded. We would also love to hear your story!

Use Your Social Circle- Do you know the Deputy Mayor of Paris? Or perhaps your neighbor is a curator at the Centre Pompidou? Maybe you play tennis with Bruno Julliard’s cousin’s best friend’s wife?  Like in life it’s not about what you know but who; help us spread the word.

Use Your Skills- Are you a blogger? News Reporter? On Air Personality? Host?  You can contribute just by using your sphere of influence and noting this campaign. Your support to expand our relevance will not be over looked.

The last thing the world needs are less expressions of Love, positivity and creativity. Help Cinterra keep this prolific outpouring of expression alive while simultaneously documenting a pivotal change for the future.

Art. Creation. Expression. Love.


Sincerely,
Jess Canty 
Filmmaker / CinterraPics.Com

story:
The Idea

Norbert Otieno,23, is a young artist born, raised and educated in Nairobi's Kibera slums. He acknowledges that not all the kids in the slum get the rare opportunity like he did of quality education and talent naturing. It is for this reason that he has founded 'art to better lives'- an initiative to nature the creative art's ability of kids in Kibera slum. He lives with the illusion that they can use their talents to better their lives.

Funds: Raising and Usage

Art to better lives looks forward to raising $ 2200 to acquire resources and equipments to train the kids: water paints, oil paints, canvas, pencils, white boards, sugar papers, brushes, pallet knives... During the training the program aims to provide snacks and refreshments. 

For this campaign, anyone who donates between $5 to $50 gets a large photo of original art by Norbert. For donations between $50 to $100, one gets original art by one of the kids posted to them. If a single donor gives over $500, he or she get an original canvas oilpaint by Norbert. 

The Impact

Instead of kids feeling frastrated about their hardships in the slum, the project can inspire them to feel good about their talents. The project aims toshow the children of the great achievement that can come their way if they take advantage of their natural talents to change their lives.

As a person, Norbert is living proof that talent in the slum can help achieve sustainable progress - he sells profesional art work.(Email: nonorbert186@gmail.com to request samples of his previous works. He is currently working on his website coming soon.)

He has previously conducted similar trainings as shown in the pictures.

Risks & Challenges

In the past, he has relied on the sales of his work and funds from Margaret Halpin and Charles Desantis from Georgetown. This implies that past trainings have been on fixed inflexible budgets.
