Please know that you are participating in creating a permanent work for Wall of Women Colorado, supporting an entire community of all ages through art and engagement, and strengthening efforts to gather and focus on healing all over the world.Donation to Wall of Women Colorado ~ completed Indra's Net value@ $3,000
All funds raised above and beyond this goal will be used to generate documentation and distribution of the day’s events, reproductions in digital giclee prints, an artists' book to accompany future community net events and a book to be reproduced that will include photographs and documentation of the prayers and thoughts donated to the project.
Campaign Sharing Helps
Please use your social media to help. Share widely - email friends, family, and supporting community. Go ahead and use the handy Indigogo share tools.   This net is a manifestation of our connections, please ask yours to join ours!

Thank you so much and we hope to see many of you in Colorado!

story:
About the project

The artwork we are designing for PK will be created by a group of his artistic and architectural collaborators and colleagues. FLUX, the non-profit arts organization that PK helped found, will be the sponsor of the project and will be the steward of the funds raised through this campaign. As FLUX is a 501c3, all donations to this fund are tax-deductible. 

We will be working on identifying a possible installation locations in the city of San Francisco over the next few months. As we narrow down our options for a location, we will begin to flesh out the design of the artwork. It is our hope that it can be -- like everything that FLUX has created -- a collaborative process in its design, fabrication, and installation. 

The aim of the work will be to inspire awe and instigate connections between those who visit the work. This may take the form of a bench that allows people to sit together and take in a sweeping view; a sculpture that encourages both contemplation and conversation in a beautiful space; or a structure that provides gathering space and shade with whimsical and thoughtful details that echo its surroundings.

It's important to us that the artwork is installed in an outdoor space that is publicly accessible. PK's work often sought to evoke the natural world -- he looked to the landscape to find inspiration for and connection to the buildings and sculptures he helped design. It's our hope that what we create in his memory can be situated somewhere that allows people to take in the beauty of our city's landscape, something he truly loved. 

What we need

We are looking for support in the following ways for this project: 

  • Financial support to fund the design, fabrication, and installation of the artwork (all donations are tax-deductible)
  • Connection to people at the San Francisco Arts Commission, the San Francisco Parks & Rec Department, and the Presidio Trust to discuss possibilities for installation

What you receive

As part of this memorial artwork, we will be making a memento connected to the work for all our supporters. This object will be something small that you can keep with you as a memory PK and the joy and passion he brought to the world as a designer, artist, architect, instigator, and maker.

Anyone who makes a donation of $50 or more will receive the memento.

story:
Who Are We and What Are We Doing?

SMUSH Gallery is an artspace dedicated to creative and community work. We produce a range of events and workshops in the disciplines of visual art, dance, literary arts, music, and more. We also offer rehearsal, performance, and exhibition rentals at incredibly affordable rates.

SMUSH Gallery exists in large part because of the artists who come through our doors, whether to work, show and share, see, or listen. In the Summer of 2019, we would love to be able to give back to our community of artists by offering no-cost space for them to work.

Residency applications will open February 2019.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for $2,000 to cover residency program costs. Full funding means totally free space for selected artists for 5 weeks of residencies. More-than-full funding means we extend our residency program and offer MORE free space to artists.

About that $2,000...
Space - $1,250
Administration - $450 
Supplies - $125
Utilities & Insurance - $175

... this is where it goes! 

If we don't secure the full $2,000, we’ll offer partial subsidies (not totally free space) to selected artists with the funds we have. 

What you get is warmth in your heart, kindled by the knowledge that you are making valuable opportunities for artists and enriching your community & world. <3

The Impact

SMUSH Gallery is an artist-run space, which means we know just how valuable it is to be gifted space to create work. Your contributions will open the doors to working artists, keep the lights on, and help artists sustain their artistic practices in a space that we lovingly care for.

Every $5 subsidizes 1 residency hour.

Every $60 subsidizes 1 full residency day.

...and every penny counts! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If a financial contribution isn’t in the cards, you can still help us!!

Share our Indiegogo page on your Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, emails, and however else you connect with your communities.

Ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about our efforts.

Come to a show, exhibition, or workshop, and check out all there is to love about SMUSH. <3

story:
Summary

Background

Hi, we are Saks Afridi and Qinza Najm, two Pakistani-American artists based in NYC. We need your help in making our  art installation a reality. This has been accepted to be installed permanently in a park in Karachi, Pakistan in September 2019.

 

The installation.
It consists of a seesaw divided by a double-sided mirrored wall. The wall has an opening in the center-bottom area where the seesaw is situated. The height of the opening is such that when children ride the seesaw, they can see and interact with each other at eye level. However when adults ride it, they mostly see their own reflections.

 

Concept
This piece is about the loss of the innocence of childhood. Children are naturally open-minded and carry no preconceived notions about others. As we grow into adulthood, our opinions change and many of us become more jaded. Labels take shape while tolerance diminishes. The sculpture encourages people to embrace differences and reconnect with their inner child. By accepting others as they are, we break down the walls that keep us apart, while celebrating diversity and encouraging self-reflection. 

The Artists
Saks Afridi and Qinza Najm are both interdisciplinary artists whose individual work you can explore at saksafridi.com and qinzanajm.com respectively.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Development Costs.
To make this installation happen, we need $10,000
The funds will go into fabrication, installation and other related expenses. The mirror-finished double-sided wall will be made from polished stainless steel. Achieving this mirror finish, fabricating the structure and installation is a somewhat costly process.We will be working with a  trusted and meticulous team of metal fabricators on all aspects from sourcing to fabrication to the final install. We have made some early tests with the fabricator and feel confident in the result.

 

Rewards


For those amazing people
Pledging $3000+
We will dedicate a plaque of appreciation to you, proudly displayed on the side of the sculpture.

Pledging $2000+
We will give you a tabletop model of the sculpture.

Pledging $1000+
We’ll treat you to a meal and studio visits with both artists, followed by an art walk in New York City.

Pledging $500+
You will get a 11 X 14 size print of either artist’s work.
Please visit each artist website and selected options can be discussed.
www.saksafridi.com & www.qinzanajm.com

Pledging $100
We will email you a one-of-a-kind photograph from somewhere in Pakistan, of a mirror with your name (or message of choice) creatively reflected in it. These photos will be taken in October during the time of the Biennale. 

Pledging $50
We will email you a digitally signed high resolution photo of the final installation. 

 

Pledging $25
We will send you a desktop wallpaper of the installation and an Instagram shout-out.

All backers will receive mentions of gratitude on our websites and our social profiles.
If we do not reach our goal, we will use whatever funds we have raised towards the project and try our best to get it done well and on time.

 

Impact

While we are both American citizens, our birth country, Pakistan, is very dear to us. The average person in Pakistan doesn’t get many opportunities to engage with public art. An installation like this will get people of all ages to not only enjoy but also to think and reflect. We’ve had this idea for years and to  install this in a park in Pakistan feels is a perfect location to have the first iteration of this work.


Both artists have executed large scale projects in the past.
In addition to being an artist, Saks is also a Creative Director in advertising and is accustomed to handling large scale productions. He recently held his first NY solo show where he worked with a team of 16 people fabricating different aspects of the show.
In addition to being an artist, Qinza is also a PhD in Psychology. In the past, she has taught and led workshops in the US and Pakistan. She has led teams in her performance art practice at museums and shows around the country.

We assure you we will execute this project with the utmost care.

 

Risks & Challenges

We are working closely with a trusted fabricator.. We anticipate things to go smoothly but sometimes things can get tricky in Pakistan. The dollar exchange rate has made life very expensive and supply and labor rates are going up by the day. To avoid the rates of steel going higher, we have, in a LEAP OF FAITH and OUR OWN FUNDS, purchased the supplies. By starting this campaign in July, we are giving ourselves suitable time to fabricate the work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, we totally understand. We ask you to please share this project on your social profiles in the hopes of raising enough awareness that will lead to full funding.

Thank you

Saks Afridi & Qinza Najm

story:
Hello friends,

This is my newest project for an art book in which I will put selected works in the recent years. In the book I present a concept art of characters, illustrations, quick digital sketches and works with traditional ink.

The book is expected to be released between September and October. It will include 120 A4 pages.

What I want to achieve is to raise enough money to print the edition that few of you will own . This also includes numbering the album as a collector's edition.

My plan is to print 500 pieces of the album with which I will end the campaign.

 

I would greatly appreciate if you want to get a copy because I do it for you!

story:
What is Actionplay?

Actionplay is an NYC-based 501(c)(3) programming, outreach, and education organization dedicated to providing people on the autism spectrum and related conditions equal access to education, arts, and culture. Actionplay is dedicated to improving the lives of individuals on the autism spectrum, their families, and the community at large.

2017 has been amazing year for Actionplay!

On Saturday November 18th, the Actionplay Chorus performed "Rise Up" on HBO's "Night of Too Many Stars" with Broadway star Cynthia Erivo and Jodi DiPiazza. 

 

Other notable Actionplay Chorus performances this year took place at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, Lincoln Center, and with the Greenwich Village Orchestra.

Actionplay created new partnerships across New York City and led theatre, music, and film programs at ART/NY,  Center for All Abilities, Shorefront Y, and Ohel Bais Ezra. Our ART/NY participants devised an original musical together called "Surreality TV" and performed to audiences of hundreds!

We Need Your Support 

We have BIG plans for 2018!  We are raising funds in order to:

  • Grow our inclusive theatre, music, and film programs to serve 3 new locations, directly serving 50 more individuals on the autism spectrum
  • Launch our new Audition Workshop for adults with autism and other developmental differences, who are interested in pursuing the goal of becoming a professional actor on camera and/or on the stage. This class will feature professional coaches along with autistic self-advocates who will help our cohort of students prepare monologues, headshots, and audition tape. The final project is a showcase of monologues and scenes in front of a panel of casting agents and managers. 
  • Launch our self-advocacy mentorship program
  • Serve 5 new cultural institutions with Actionplay’s ACT professional development training model
  • Increase our Bingledorf Scholarship fund to support tuition fees in reaching more communities with our AIMS program

Join our Community

For sharing your support, you'll receive:

  • Our deepest appreciation for helping us to sustain and grow our programs!
  • Awesome rewards including downloads of our greatest hits album "We Don't Wanna Fit In", a DVD of our most recent show "Surreality TV", tickets to our Holiday Fundraiser and upcoming shows, and songs written especially for YOU by our very own Actionplay Chorus!

Thank you for your support! To learn more about Actionplay, please visit www.actionplay.org
story_txt:
What is Actionplay?Actionplay is an NYC-based 501(c)(3) programming, outreach, and education organization dedicated to providing people on the autism spectrum and related conditions equal access to education, arts, and culture. Actionplay is dedicated to improving the lives of individuals on the autism spectrum, their families, and the community at large.2017 has been amazing year for Actionplay! On Saturday November 18th, the Actionplay Chorus performed "Rise Up" on HBO's "Night of Too Many Stars" with Broadway star Cynthia Erivo and Jodi DiPiazza.  Other notable Actionplay Chorus performances this year took place at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, Lincoln Center, and with the Greenwich Village Orchestra.Actionplay created new partnerships across New York City and led theatre, music, and film programs at ART/NY,  Center for All Abilities, Shorefront Y, and Ohel Bais Ezra. Our ART/NY participants devised an original musical together called "Surreality TV" and performed to audiences of hundreds!We Need Your Support We have BIG plans for 2018!  We are raising funds in order to:
Grow our inclusive theatre, music, and film programs to serve 3 new locations, directly serving 50 more individuals on the autism spectrum
Launch our new Audition Workshop for adults with autism and other developmental differences, who are interested in pursuing the goal of becoming a professional actor on camera and/or on the stage. This class will feature professional coaches along with autistic self-advocates who will help our cohort of students prepare monologues, headshots, and audition tape. The final project is a showcase of monologues and scenes in front of a panel of casting agents and managers. 
Launch our self-advocacy mentorship program

Serve 5 new cultural institutions with Actionplay’s ACT professional development training model


Increase our Bingledorf Scholarship fund to support tuition fees in reaching more communities with our AIMS program
Join our CommunityFor sharing your support, you'll receive:
Our deepest appreciation for helping us to sustain and grow our programs!
Awesome rewards including downloads of our greatest hits album "We Don't Wanna Fit In", a DVD of our most recent show "Surreality TV", tickets to our Holiday Fundraiser and upcoming shows, and songs written especially for YOU by our very own Actionplay Chorus!
Thank you for your support! To learn more about Actionplay, please visit www.actionplay.org

story:
Who Are We?

Originating as the Utah contingent of the Burning Man camp Armageddon, Salt Mind has been Arting for 5 years. Our appetite to provide people with unforgettable experiences through interactive art is forever growing.

We are a crew of roughly 20 with backgrounds in design, engineering, photography, fashion, environmental science, and more. External to Burning Man we have a growing presence at our regional burn, Element 11, and host several annual events in Utah.

 

 

EXTRA EXTRA, READ ALL ABOUT IT!!!

Welcome Home Receives Honoraria from BMORG

Salt Mind is one of 70 groups chosen by the Burning Man Organization to receive a 2019 Honoraria Grant which will partially fund the build of Welcome Home. This bizarrely tall parlour in the sky invites participants to relax and explore intimate interactions from an unexpected vantage.

Project Details
BRC Honoraria

What Do We Need?

In order for Salt Mind to function and bring these experiences to the people (on and off playa) there are a number of necessary expenses.

Here is where your donations will go.
- Build materials and expenses for Welcome Home
- Purchase of an enclosed trailer for transporting Welcome Home and the Classic Slide
- Classic Slide repairs/updates


 

By supporting Salt Mind you are allowing us to continue our pursuit of the unexpected and desire to share that with the world. Help us build big shit so you can come play on it!

 

Don't forget to share our campaign.

story:
Inner Radiance is a powerful 44-Card Deck that has been made with the intention for you to see the light that is within, so you can become the highest version of yourself & let your Inner Radiance shine. This deck was created from sisterhood, healing, laughter, love & joy. The watercolor images capture the essence of our beautiful Earth. The deck has a Universe of its own & we are so excited to share her with you. The affirmations & essential oils chosen were created from personal experiences of Samantha's self-love journey. They are magical, healing & deeply rooted from her heart to yours.

Essential oils are not mandatory for this deck. The affirmations are powerful on their own & will be amazing for you in your daily life. However, essential oils will enhance your experience. If you need guidance on getting the highest quality essential oils for this deck, visit Samantha's website here ~  https://www.selflovewithsam.com/essential-oils

Inner Radiance is for the woman who is ready to connect with her highest self on the deepest level. For the woman who needs guidance on her path, her relationships & her life. For the woman who craves sisterhood & connections that don’t fade away. For the woman who wants to get in touch with her inner-goddess. For the woman who is ready to drop the negativity & let her Inner Radiance shine.

Inner Radiance Includes:

  • 44 Cards with beautiful watercolor images, positive affirmations & essential oils.
  • A gorgeous Inner Radiance box that is of the highest quality for you to keep your cards in.

Inner Radiance is an intuition based deck but there will be an instructional card that teaches you how to set your intention once you get the deck. You can pull cards daily for yourself first thing in the morning, after you meditate, during or after your yoga practice, or any time you need guidance in your life. The deck is there for you when you need it. Lean on her for guidance, support & love.

Why are we using INDIEGOGO?

  • This platform is going to allow us to get the highest quality box & cards for all of you at the most inexpensive cost.
  • Once we hit our goal of $6,000 we will be able to produce right away & purchase a bulk order of 500 decks which allows us to get them at the lowest cost for you!
  • It will allow both the artist & creator to get paid for their hard work & dedication to Inner Radiance.

The Impact

Inner Radiance is a powerful tool for self-development, for healing, for guidance, for falling back in love with yourself & your life. Getting this deck out into the world is going to help thousands of women on their self-love journey. It has the power to change every woman's life who touches it because of the power it holds. I truly believe this is so needed for the dark world we live in today. When you contribute & pre-order your Inner Radiance Deck you are not only helping us with our dream but you are also investing in yourself, your growth & helping hundreds of women be able to get this deck into their hands. This takes a village of sisters who are willing to rise together. 

Risks & Challenges

If we do not reach our goal of $6,000 we will not be able to do a bulk order. This means the deck will be at a much higher price. We want this deck to be at the most affordable price for you, reaching our goal is huge for us and for everyone else!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share with your friends, your team if you are involved in doTERRA or Young Living & or anyone else you know who will benefit from Inner Radiance! We can't do this without you!
  • Follow along our social media pages! - http://www.instagram.com/selflovewithsam - http://www.instagram.com/jenwallahsart 

We thank you so much for your support!
We are grateful for each & every one of you who has contributed. Sending all of our love to you!

Be on the lookout for your gorgeous Inner Radiance Deck in July!

story:
Who am I?

My name is Ivy Manska. I'm currently a student at the College for Creative Studies in Detroit, MI. I will be graduating in May with a BFA in illustration with a minor in fine art. I draw, paint, and was recently acquainted with printmaking. 

I spent last semester in Toronto as an exchange student, but I'm eager to explore further. I've always been attracted to Iceland for its otherworldly landscape, so I started applying for artist residencies there first. The following day I was pleasantly surprised to be offered an 80-day residency at the Heima residency in Seydisfjordur from August to October. 

A Call for Donation

The residency is on an eastern fjord of Iceland located in a town with a population of around 600. I will be in a shared studio with 5 other artists from around the world. There are opportunities for gallery shows in Iceland as well as when I arrive home in October. I've yet to spend any prolonged period of time somewhere so isolated. I'm hoping this opportunity will benefit my personal growth, and strongly influence my artistic approaches.

I will come out of this residency with a fully developed body of work inspired by a multitude of subjects, but heavily influenced by experiences in Iceland. It offers landscapes and wildlife that more align with the work that I've made in the past and work that I want to continue creating. 

Any donation will go towards the residency fee, travel costs, art supplies, and necessities. Donations would also go towards printing costs for any pieces I create on this adventure! For example, I hope to explore zine-making on this trip!

What You Get

For such a personal project, I wanted to be able to give back a product for those who can donate! I'm offering stickers, to prints, then original pieces. I'm open to suggestions for products, but I'm very limited on time as I'm currently in the last semester of my undergraduate program. 

Other Ways to Help

Feel free to share this campaign as well as my work! 

Campaign - https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/iceland-arti...

Website - ivymanska.com

Instagram - instagram.com/noslug

Facebook - facebook.com/ivymanska

story:
Feel Your Feelings

There was nothing like the lyrics of early 2000's emo songs that sparked imagery in my brain I just had to draw. For years, I've been making art from the lyrics of Taking Back Sunday, My Chemical Romance, Dashboard Confessional, and so many more. This collection takes that love to the next level, with prints created by hand by yours truly. If you're like me, emo music makes you want to head bang and sing as loud as you can. Each design encapsulates that energy and intensity, romanticism and longing, so that you can carry it with you in a 5"x7" package wherever you see fit.

Why now? Well, because soon I will be attending a coding bootcamp, and the tension and the terror of paying for it is real. Getting this campaign fully funded would mean graduating from a coding bootcamp without debt. For the past few years, I've worked for arts education nonprofits and at Patagonia, places with socially minded missions that I can truly stand behind. The freedom to continue this trend, and not just take a job to pay off a loan, is something I want to strive for. 

 

That's What You Get (When You Donate)

You get a print that soothes your little emo kid soul, I get a little bit closer to my career goals.

I've been in a holding pattern, but that ends now. This summer, I'll be attending an immersive coding bootcamp in SF, which has a tuition of approximately $16k. (I know. I know.)

The program itself has a scholarship (currently applying for it) that covers $8k leaving me responsible for the last $8,000. This remaining tuition is where the funds raised here are headed, save the cost of creating and shipping the prints themselves. In the event more than $8,000 is raised, the rest will go towards living expenses in SF for the 3 months I'll be there. 

But back to what YOU get!  Each of these designs has been a labor of love. They're crafted to convey the feeling of each lyric in its song, so that the experience of listening to the music and looking at the print are one and the same. I came up with each concept myself, drew them myself, and printed them myself (at local nonprofit Laika Press!), so that no two are exactly alike. These prints are truly the best of me. 

Check out the FAQ's for more details on the process!

This Print Is Proof (I Know You Know)

When you work at a desk, whether you're a student, a professional, or an artist, the space immediately around you takes on importance. For me, having a little inspiration around, in a bit of artwork, has always made a world of difference. These lyrics prints were crafted specifically to bring you the feel of the music with just a glance.  Maybe you can't rock out with all your might to that song right now, singing the chorus til the building shakes, air guitar held high, feet stomping to the beat. But you'll still get that feeling.

Each print is small enough to put up anywhere (5" by 7"), but big enough to be noticeable and give whatever space you choose a dose of personality. They're imbued with affection and humanity through the handmade design and print process, and are printed on thick paper with a deckled (rough) edge. 

Apart from that, funding this campaign would give me a fighting chance. Many bootcamp attendees throw down that tuition money as if it's lunch. I am not one of these people. The ability to start from a level playing field with my peers by graduating without debt would be a game-changer. My ultimate goal is to combine my skills as an engineer with my experience as a designer and elevate the visibility of nonprofits like the ones I've worked with in the past. These operations are filled with talented, passionate people, but desperately need a technological facelift to compete with huge corporations for our attention. I have seen how the right tools can make them more effective and visible, and I'm determined to provide those tools. 

 

Risks & Challenges (If It's F*cked Up, I'm To Blame)

Risks for this campaign include: 

  • If there's a large response, creating the prints will take more time, delaying the date the prints would arrive to your door.
  • The cost of shipping could be way higher than I've anticipated

I've made quite a few of the prints and I'm confident that this is a feasible project numbers-wise, but if the response is overwhelming, they would take more time to produce and to therefore land in your mailbox. But to be honest, this would be my favorite problem.

I've estimated the cost of shipping each package type and have categorized the brackets accordingly, so this is really only an issue if I've drastically overlooked a certain cost.

 

Print Anything (Else)

So you don't like emo song lyrics, eh? Well, I guess we'll agree to disagree. However, I do make other kinds of art, in case you're still interested in buying some art.

My etsy store: https://www.etsy.com/shop/glorimade

My art: https://www.instagram.com/glorimade/

Psst, interested in a custom lyric print? I miiiight be able to do that. Message me to learn more.

If contributing financially to this is just not in the cards, no hard feelings. After all, we're in the same boat. If you're down, please share this campaign with people who would like a little more art in their life, especially niche communities you're a part of that miss rocking out to their feelings. 

Also, here's a playlist! 

Thanks for reading!

story:
We Are From Dust - Supporting Working Artists

The global COVID-19 pandemic has strained all of us, but particularly hard hit are the working artists who don't enjoy the privilege of a financial safety net when the bottom drops out. We Are From Dust is committed to supporting working artists through exhibition of, and fair payment for their work.

Your donation will go directly to We Are From Dust's exhibiting artists whose works are on display at Point San Pablo Harbor in Richmond, CA. Funds raised beyond our goal will also allow us to build capacity to install our next set of five exhibitions — supporting yet more artists — when the world is once again ready to connect around participatory art. Thank you!  

We Are From Dust is made up of Burners and non-Burners dedicated to transforming people’s lives through participatory art. In the spirit of inclusion, collaboration and communal effort, all are welcome to join us in this effort. Together, we have amassed over 130 years working in various capacities for the Burning Man Project, and our experience has benefitted the development of art projects around the world.

WAFD's inaugural exhibition at Point San Pablo Harbor has been a great success, featuring artworks from professional working artists Kate Raudenbush (Future’s Past), Michael Christian (Asterpod), Paige Tashner (Purr Pods), and Peter Hazel (Niloticus).

Rewards and Perks

Here are some of the amazing and unique perks we like to offer in return for your support.

Temple, Boat and Dust print by Philip Volkers

Reared in Steel print by Philip Volkers

----------------------

Risks & Challenges

We Are From Dust is fundraising to support the exhibiting artists at our Point San Pablo Harbor art park, as well as extending our vision to showcase the transformational power of participatory art in public spaces. We are dependent on clients, partners, and collaborators to make this mission a reality, and we believe the risk when artists cannot support themselves is self-evident.

Need to connect direct? Kindly contact us directly if you would like to discuss a donation outside the scope of this crowdfunding campaign.

Need to connect direct? Kindly contact us directly if you would like to discuss a donation outside the scope of this crowdfunding campaign.

story:
INSPIRATION

As a kid I would save up quarters I earned from chores and buy super bouncy balls from the coin machines at the grocery store. Over time I had a big mason jar full of the crazy colored superballs - my favorites were the rainbow sparkles ones and but the marble patterned ones always bounced the highest, and whenever I got the chance I'd dump them out from some place up high and delight in their crazy bouncing and wild trajectories! This project is an ode to that childlike joy but built on the serious infrastructure of heavy industrial machinery.

The Meaning Behind the Sculpture

The title "Bounce Back" signifies the resilience we all have inside to bounce back from seemingly impossible situations and sometimes we find answers in unlikely places for finding new ways to bounce back. Using industrial equipment to produce a playful, larger than life kinetic sculpture reminds us that juxtaposing the serious and the playful can produce surprising results. But it also goes deeper than that. Recognizing there's a behind the scenes aspect to everything we do can help keep things in perspective. In this case, I'm fascinated by how the raw elements of nearly everything we experience, the things we consume and everything we use to get through our days, was moved, carried or lifted by a kinetic machine engineered to bring us a little part of reality to interact with. We can only have the interactive sides of life because there's some serious processes at work behind the scenes. My dad was an engineer who taught me how to investigate the infrastructure of things to see how they tick and how to build things to last a lifetime and my mom is an artist who taught me the secrets of oil painting. Bounce Back combines those influences into a joyful, thoughtful and interactive work of art for all to enjoy! I hope you will also contemplate the hidden elements that make up life and find joy and resilience in it all.

A 2019 Black Rock City Honoraria Recipient

My name is Sarah Gonsalves Firefly, aka Sassy -Galaxy. After 12 years of bringing art and shows to Burning Man since 2005,  I'm  honored to be a 2019 Art Honoraria recipient for my kinetic, musical sculpture titled Bounce Back.  I'm raising the remaining funds not covered in the grant through this Indiegogo Campaign. Myself and the rest of my crew are volunteering all of our time to make this art piece come to life!

You may recognize some of the projects I've been involved with in the past. In 2013 - 2015, I was one of four lead artists for PedalBump, A Pedal-Powered Bumper Cars Derby Under the Big Top and also a theme camp leader for Red Nose District on the Esplanade! For several years I helped run live shows at Dustfish, one of the few live music stages on the Esplanade. In my earliest years on Playa, I stage managed for Vau de Vire Society for Center Camp Performances and Fire Conclave Fire Shows.  Most recently, last year in 2018, I brought my Philosoph-Bots: talking upcycled Robots  from the future, holding court and serving s'mores around their fire pit made from the wreckage of their time travel ship.

2019 is my year to bring an exclusive Sassy-Galaxy original kinetic large-scale sculpture to the Playa for all to experience and enjoy!  My goal is to also give it a life beyond as public art somewhere after the event! I have a great team joining me as my core build crew and I hope you will support us in any way you can.

 

The Design

Bounce Back is a sleek colorful contraption that transforms into a kinetic wonder when activated. A 2-story hexagonal, plexiglass box sits empty except for a contraption inside that reaches to the pointed roof. Surrounded by a ring of rounded benches for an audience, it invites the curious. On closer inspection, the contraption is a bucket elevator powered by stationary pedal carts parked near the base. When the contraption is activated, the clear chamber fills with motion and energy of the elevator scooping and lifting small brightly colored bouncy balls to be released from the heights in a bouncing kinetic explosion of color and trajectories seemingly wild -- but fully enclosed. At night, Bounce Back has a phosphorescent glow whether still or activated. The bright colors and tall structure will stand out as a beacon of colorful fun. The shape, like that of a grain silo, is almost instantly recognizable as one ingrained in our collective memories, but with a transformative twist.

One or more people can pedal the carts (with age/height adjustable seats) to activate the elevator. Speeding up the elevator takes more pedal power and may encourage people to work together. A shared suspense builds as more and more balls go up to a hanging basket. When enough balls go up they’re released to bounce wildly inside - Glee and music created by the bouncing balls will fill the air when that happens! Long strings hang outside the glass: pull a string and a hidden lever flips up – try and bounce balls higher! The flipper action is probably addictive. Fabric covered bouncy benches provide fun seats for contemplating the spectacle, the original art that decorates the surfaces, or listening to the music created in a unique never to be repeated performance by the bouncing balls. I imagine it will become a popular gathering spot to meet up or recharge, “Let’s meet up at Bounce Back” will be a rally cry. In addition, tall dusters will be on hand for those who want to get swept up in the moment and keep Bounce Back clean. Video coming soon...

 

The Bounce Back Team

My Core Crew is made up of my best friends!

Ambra "Bacon Bits" Sutherlin is an art guru and she first introduced me to Burning Man convincing me to go back in 2005 even though she herself couldn't go for her first time till a few years later.

Mona "Drumroll Please" Holmes-Nisker welcomed me to L.A. with a big smile and open arms! We ran the meal plan together for Red Nose District in 2012, and have laughed our way through many other projects and shenanigans in the years since.

Shawn "Chikadee" Stang came to a PedalBump fundraiser back in 2012 and has been an integral part of all our projects and a best friend ever since because she just is that amazing!

Araceli Grateful, who I met at RND, shows up with a hammer and magical secrets everywhere she goes - need I say more?!

Many other volunteers have stepped up to build on weekends this Spring and Summer! Special thanks to my husband, Kevin Bourque, for the music and sound programming expertise and to fellow burners Susan Jones for help with wood work, Enara Hug for her fabric and sewing expertise and Jacquelyn Dalot and her daughter Ava for checking all the math twice before cutting.

Bounce Back Fundraising Goals

Please help by donating funds or sharing this campaign! The Art Grant from Burning Man Arts covers a portion for the costs to build Bounce Back. This campaign is meant to raise the funds to cover the remaining amount needed to get us all the way to the Playa!

All of our time, expertise and artistic contributions are volunteered. Your financial donations go directly to cover hard costs such as:

  • Industrial rated materials so the piece is safely designed
  • Specialized technical and power systems to make magic out of chaos
  • Reliable transportation to and from Burning Man (I drive the Truck!)
  • Paint, parts and pieces for the finishing touches!

THANK YOU's

We have brainstormed creative ways to thank our donors and have sourced some fun interactive and in-kind donations as perks to giving so that funds remain in the project bucket where they belong.

Thank you for all your support!

Sassy Galaxy and the Bounce Back Crew

story:
Lyle Bergman's Scratch-n'-Win Picture Play is a win-every-time game of chance that rewards you with a delightful and possibly distasteful picture! 

Win any of 20 pictures spanning the full range of life's desirables: Ice Cream Sundae, Mansion, New Computer, Tits, Inner Peace, Samurai, Diamond Necklace, Exploding Mind, Fast Car, Golden Retriever, and more -- plus top *rare* prizes of Golden Retriever in a Hat, Veiny Penis, and Wet P*ssy.

It's charming -- and graphic -- imagery like you've never seen before! 

For as little as $3, you can help bring this cheerful product to life. The art and design work for the project is complete, but we need your support to cover printing for the scratch-n'-win tickets.

Once you see these big, bright, shiny 4" x 6" tickets -- and the surprise picture that each ticket reveals -- you'll want to collect them all!  Or gift them to party guests, friends, roommates, bar mates, coworkers, neighbors, and family (but not children)!

All the best,

Lyle and friends



FAQs

Is this a real lottery? 

No, sillypants.  It is not a real lottery.  You can't win Inner Peace, a Mansion, a Samurai, or anything else depicted on the ticket.  Your prize is the picture itself -- and the joy of maybe, just maybe, finding the elusive Golden Retriever in a Hat, Veiny Penis, or Wet P*ssy.

Is there real nudity? 

Yes.

Who is Lyle Bergman? 

One of the great inventors of the twentieth-century, Lyle put the propeller on the propeller beanie and the tickler on the French tickler.  Before Lyle, the yo dangled without purpose at the end of a string.  Children were sad.  If you summon the toy, it will return to your hand, Lyle said.  And the yo-yo was born.  

Because Lyle isn't great with computers, he has enlisted the creatives at Dear Adam (www.DearAdamObjects.com - previous Kickstarter: http://kck.st/Zfu7qJ) to help him with this important campaign. With special thanks to medunecer (www.medunecer.com).

Why Indiegogo?

All of the art and design for this project is complete. The only thing left to do is pay the printer so they can print the tickets. We are working with a leading commercial printer of scratch-n'-win tickets (they've done scratch-n'-win promotions for Subway, Chevrolet and other big brands), so we are confident they will do a good job, on time.

In our last crowdfunding campaign (http://kck.st/Zfu7qJ) we were lightning-fast at order fulfillment and got everyone their rewards on time. We will fill orders quickly for this campaign, too.

Thanks for your support and GOOD LUCK!

story:
The Flight of the Inkstained Succubus

It takes a lot of fuel to keep the old airship flying, and sometimes, it's hard to come by,

Inkstained Sucucubus is a small press that (fictitiously) operates off a steampunk pirate airship. On the ground, we are devoted to science fiction and fantasy, often with a queer bent. 

Book sales aren't what they were, and even long-respected publishers like Amber Quill and Samhain are shutting their doors. To supplement the travel budget, and put our books in front of more eyes, we expanded into a craft line, Conspiracy Arts for SF conventions, The Carpenter's Wife for Renaissance fairs and SCA. Also, when we are too ill for computer work, we can sit and let our fingers accomplish something.

There's always one problem with any merchant business: storage space.

We're rapidly outgrowing our available space and as we move into selling at outdoor events, we also have that equipment to worry about.

We scored a major break with the sunshade this year, and it was as though Hermes smiled on us and said “Go Thou Forth and Sell All The Things.”

That's why we're running the crowdfunding. We need some seed money. We're not saying “give us money.” We're saying “Here's a chance to get some exclusive stuff,  and send us on our way.”

Our ultimate funding goal is $5000. That's not a lot of start-up capital.

What we plan to buy:

1) A year of off-site storage. Gabriel's apartment is far too crowded right now.

2) A band saw. With this, Gabriel can cut custom shaped paddles, no longer limited to this shape:


and Angelia can do the fictional street signs


3) A power sander for these projects  Acquired by way of Ibotta rebates.

4) Wood for these projects. Cloth for hats.

5) A button press This has been acquired for nearly nothing, through judicious use of mystery shopping and internet rewards sites, However, we do need a circle cutter, and button parts. The gods help them as help themselves.

6) Display set-ups: A lattice wall, another couple of tables, a hanging rack.

7) A microphone and soundproofing so Gabriel can begin recording audiobooks

8) Space at the following events, as well as others:

Renaissance Fair of the Ozarks, Fayetteville AR This has been specifically funded by a donor

FroliCon, Atlanta GA

Southern Delta Church of Wicca's Beltane, Memphis

River City Comic Expo, Little Rock AR

Hypericon, Nashville TN

Mid-South Renaissance Festival, Memphis TN This has been specifically funded by a donor.

Memphit FurMeet, Memphis TN

Cooper Young Street Festival, Memphis Tn

MidSouth Pride, Memphis TN

ConTraFlow, New Orleans

Festival of Souls, Memphis TN

ConTraception, Independence MO



The perks.

 

This is the part we all love.

Each level gets all the perks of the previous level, plus the listed

$1 gets you our heartfelt thanks, and your name embroidered in the Roll of Sponsors on our tent's decorative scallops

$5 gets you an ebook. Any ebook from the Inkstained Succubus backlist, or the Angelia Sparrow back list.

$15 gets you an audiobook. These choices are more limited. We're using ACX and you'll have your choice there.

$25 gets you a paperback. Any paperback from the Inkstained Succubus list. Angelia Sparrow backlist subject to availability.

$30 gets a 16 card tarot reading. This is the What You Need To Know reading.  Pictures of the spread, and interpretation will be emailed.

$50 gets you a hat. It can be a Yoda hat, a bag hat, a Jayne hat, a princess hat with long braids or cinnabuns, a Valkryie helmet. If we make this hat, it is yours for this donation level.


$75 gets a box. Gabriel makes interesting, one of a kind boxes


$100 gets an altar plate or plaque. Your custom design, done by Gabriel.


$150. You get a character named after you in the Eight Thrones Saga, the thrilling dark future world where eight nearly-immortal people control the fate of humanity, and all of them are going slowly insane.


$200 gets a custom paddle. This is where we shine. The paddles are 24” long, solid pine. Gabriel paints, wood burns and decorates them into unique works of useful art.


$250 gets a custom shawl or scarf This can be any shawl pattern of your choosing or scarf of your liking, hand knitted or crocheted by Angelia, up to and including a Dr. Who scarf, made over the original design from Begonia Pope.


$500 gets an afghan or sweater. Hand knitted, or hand crocheted, your choice of design.


$1000 At this level, we arrange to come to an event in your area and deliver 5 signed books to you personally. (Snacks and other treats a possibility)

$5000 At this level, we throw a room party at a convention in your location, with you and five of your friends as the guests of honor. Complete autographed back list for you, one book for each of them, and dramatic readings and entertainment.


Risks & Challenges

We have proven ourselves capable of operating on a shoestring for the last three years. Even without the full amount, we can still accomplish many of our goals, as shown by the acquisition of the button maker.

If we fall short, the goals are listed in priority order, 


Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone can afford to donate. We understand this.

So, we would ask you to share the link, using indiegoogo share tools and social media. Facebook, tumblr, instagram, twitter, myspace, livejournal, Usenet, anywhere you are being read, please share us there,

Word of mouth is great too. Tell people who like books, who like hand-crafts, who are involved in the GLBT community.


Thank you!

story:
Resonator

Resonator provides:

  • A platform for Local, Regional and International Artists and Creatives
  • A space to host workshops and educational programs
  • An opportunity for international artist residencies
  • An ability to collaborate and build relationships with other artistic organiziations world wide
  • A place to gather, experiment, discuss and grow as humans

What we need

A sustainable infrastructure to keep the space alive and active.

Reaching this goal means that utilities and bills will be covered for a year giving us the time to fine tune the facilities and procedures into a sustainable system.

The Impact

The impact of art and creativity is often justified.  We believe there is a huge spectrum of reactions to music, art, and performance experiments and experiences. We hope to provide a context to engage the arts where the viewer and artist are both empowered and encouraged to discuss and debate.  

 

Risks & Challenges

This space is big, the dream is big, we seek to bring the pie out of the sky.

  • We ran a smaller space successfully for 2 years as a prototype.  Or procedures and systems have been revamped and edited multiple times to reach our current incarnation.
  • This time we have a silk-screen, relief, and etching printshop, a woodshop, a gallery and performance space on site.
  • We plan to run shop memberships, shared and private artist studios, weekly meetups and events along with quarterly international festivals.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't in a place to contribute monetarily you can still make a huge difference:

  • Tell your friends and family about our project and how they can support us.
  • Share this campaign, along with a short message, to your social media groups.
  • Message us at Resonator.ok@gmail.com about how to volunteer your time to our project.
story_txt:
Resonator
Resonator provides:

A platform for Local, Regional and International Artists and Creatives
A space to host workshops and educational programs
An opportunity for international artist residencies
An ability to collaborate and build relationships with other artistic organiziations world wide
A place to gather, experiment, discuss and grow as humans


What we need
A sustainable infrastructure to keep the space alive and active.
Reaching this goal means that utilities and bills will be covered for a year giving us the time to fine tune the facilities and procedures into a sustainable system.

The Impact
The impact of art and creativity is often justified.  We believe there is a huge spectrum of reactions to music, art, and performance experiments and experiences. We hope to provide a context to engage the arts where the viewer and artist are both empowered and encouraged to discuss and debate.  
 

Risks & Challenges
This space is big, the dream is big, we seek to bring the pie out of the sky.

We ran a smaller space successfully for 2 years as a prototype.  Or procedures and systems have been revamped and edited multiple times to reach our current incarnation.
This time we have a silk-screen, relief, and etching printshop, a woodshop, a gallery and performance space on site.
We plan to run shop memberships, shared and private artist studios, weekly meetups and events along with quarterly international festivals.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you aren't in a place to contribute monetarily you can still make a huge difference:

Tell your friends and family about our project and how they can support us.
Share this campaign, along with a short message, to your social media groups.
Message us at Resonator.ok@gmail.com about how to volunteer your time to our project.

story:
Hello friends old and new!  We are the Forest of Boom.

Who We Are:

We are a theme camp at Critical Northwest, Washington’s regional Burning Man event. We bring a great sound system, DJs that range in style from rock, to soul, hip-hop, pop, house, EDM, and psy-trance.  Our goal is to bring as much of the Burning Man spirit, wonder, and awe to Washington as we can.  Last year we were the regional's only sound camp.  One with a bar and much illuminated art.  This year, we're going even bigger.

What We Are Building This Year:

We are building a new shade structure, 3 in fact!, and dance area, one that will feel more open, create a better connection between indoor and outdoor spaces, will be easier to put up and transport, and most importantly can stand up to strong winds and weather. We are also planning on investing in our camp decor, refurbishing our giant illuminated mushrooms, adding more lighting and video projection, and building even more art to light the night in our glowing forest. And most importantly, stocking the Wildwood bar!

What We Need From You:

A donation to our camp.   

What You Get in Return:

You get to dance your ass off, drink our delicious concoctions, and if you donate $25 or more, only the best festival cup you could ever hope to have.  An engraved, double-walled, stainless steel, screw top, carabiner-handled beauty. Want 2?  Donate $50!  You can drink in style and leave no trace at the same time.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can't donate, please help spread the word.  Share our story!

story:
En octobre dernier, la Société québécoise des infrastructures a mis en vente le studio que s’était bâti Ernest Cormier, un des plus grands architectes québécois du 20e siècle. Le studio n'est toujours pas classé au patrimoine et il est à craindre qu'il perde sa vocation d'atelier.

Notre initiative

La Société pour la sauvegarde du studio Ernest Cormier est l’initiative de jeunes artistes, photographes, designers et muséologues qui se sont réunis pour acquérir l’édifice, le préserver et faire reconnaître son statut patrimonial.

Nous voulons perpétuer sa vocation d’atelier, continuer l’activité de son bâtisseur et de tous les artistes qui lui ont succédé. Ce lieu unique de notre architecture moderne doit revivre.

L'objectif de la présente campagne est d'amasser une somme de 28 000$ afin de pouvoir présenter notre offre d'achat le 31 mai prochain.

Phase 1 — Acquisition du studio 
Phase 2 — Restauration et revitalisation du lieu
Phase 3 — Implantation de notre projet



Occupation projetée du studio

Lieu de travail, de rencontres et d'échanges
Notre projet vise à terme la création d’une structure autonome: un atelier expérimental pour la recherche, la création, l’éducation et la diffusion.

Chaque année sont accueillis des participants issus de différentes disciplines liées aux arts visuels, au design graphique et à la photographie. Tout au long de leur séjour, des intervenants d'ici et d'ailleurs, qu'ils soient architectes, designers, photographes ou philosophes, sont invités à guider les participants dans leur pratique.


Les participants sont sélectionnés sur la base d’un projet qu’ils soumettent. Axé sur la culture visuelle et inspiré par la phénoménologie, le programme les amène à reconnecter avec leur vision et à développer une sensibilité à leur milieu de vie et leur contexte social. Ils sont encouragés à collaborer avec des organismes culturels et communautaires environnants dans l'élaboration de projets.

Le studio Ernest Cormier dote ses participants d’outils de réflexion critiques, pratiques, et théoriques sur la base d'une perspective culturelle large. La vie y est ponctuée de conférences, de rencontres, de lectures et de séminaires orientés vers la recherche et le travail à la fois autonome et collectif. Il met à la disposition des participants un espace de travail personnel, un laboratoire de développement photographique, une salle de rencontres et d'expositions, une bibliothèque, et différents outils servant aux observations diurnes et nocturnes. 

La liberté et la convivialité qu’offre la taille réduite du programme, la qualité exceptionnelle du site et l’excellence des intervenants invités sont autant d'atouts propres à attirer les candidats.


Revitalisation et diffusion

La Société pour la sauvegarde du Studio Ernest Cormier tient à révéler au public un lieu fondateur de notre patrimoine architectural moderne rendu presque imperceptible pour en faire à nouveau un pôle culturel majeur. C’est à travers sa visibilité, sa revitalisation et la diffusion de ses activités que nous entendons le lier à l’écosystème des institutions communautaires et culturelles qui l’entourent.

Revitalisation et restauration des jardins
Nous voulons faire de ce lieu un bien commun, un espace convivial accessible à tous. Avec l’aide de l'architecte Gilles Saucier, de la firme Saucier et Perrotte, nous entendons restaurer l’ancien jardin tel que Cormier l’avait aménagé dans les années 1920. À ces côtés, nous projetons la création d’un nouveau jardin au caractère plus contemporain composé d’une végétation variée, d’arbres et d’œuvres d’art.


Activités de diffusion
Le studio, ses participants et ses partenaires proposeront aux habitants du quartier et au public des activités telles que des projections, des performances, des expositions temporaires et des visites commentées.

Le studio Ernest Cormier n’est plus le projet d’un seul homme, il nous appartient à tous de le sauvegarder et de le considérer comme pilier de notre culture, de notre identité et de notre histoire.

**


Partenaires et collaborateurs

Notre action a reçu l'appui de nombreux organismes et acteurs des milieux de la culture, du patrimoine, de l'éducation et des affaires. Notamment:

John Zeppetelli, Directeur général et conservateur en chef — MACM;
Gilles Saucier, Architecte, Saucier + Perrotte Architectes;
France Vanlaethem, Professeure émérite de l’École de design de l’UQAM,
Présidente fondatrice de Docomomo Québec;
Céline Poisson, Directrice des études supérieures de l'École de design et responsable du DESS en architecture moderne et patrimoine;
Michael Fish, Architecte, Co-fondateur du comité Sauvons Montréal;
François Girard, réalisateur, scénariste, acteur et metteur en scène québécois;
Caroline Andrieux, Fondatrice et directrice artistique, Quartier Éphémère et Fonderie Darling 
Jacques Des Rochers, Conservateur de l'art québécois et canadien;
Koen de Winter, Designer industriel et professeur à l'École de design de l'UQAM;
Rhona Richman Kenneally, Professeure, Département de design et arts numériques, Université Concordia
Louise Pelletier, Directrice et professeure à École de design, Université du Québec à Montréal;
Martin Bressani, Directeur des études supérieures, École d’architecture de l’Université McGill;
Jacques Lachapelle, Directeur, École d’architecture, Université de Montréal;
Michèle Thériault, Directrice et commissaire, Leonard & Bina Ellen Art Gallery;
Mallory Wilson, Association canadienne d’experts-conseils en patrimoine;
Karel Martens, Artiste et designer graphique; 
Lisette Smits, Directrice de la maîtrise, Master of Voice, Sandburg Institute et commissaire;
Isabelle Gournay, Architecte et commissaire;
Aliki Economides, Historienne de l'architecture et chercheuse en résidence, Centre de recherches interdisciplinaires en études montréalaises (CRIEM).

De plus, nous développons des partenariats avec un ensemble d’organismes montréalais. Collaborez avec nous!

Fonderie Darling 
La Communauté Milton Parc
Maison de la photo de Montréal
Le Cabinet
Etc.

**
Société pour la sauvegarde du studio Ernest Cormier (OBNL)
www.studioernestcormier.org
www.facebook.com/studioernestcormier
studioernestcormier@gmail.com
Tél.: 514-586-1431


Chronologie du studio Ernest Cormier

Né à Montréal, Ernest Cormier (1885–1980) fait des études de génie civil à l'École polytechnique de Montréal. En 1908, il poursuit des études d'architecture à l'École des beaux-arts de Paris.

En 1918, il revient à Montréal pour s'installer à titre d'architecte et d'ingénieur.

En 1921, Ernest Cormier achète un terrain sur la rue Saint-Urbain pour se construire un atelier d'artiste. Ce lot fait alors partie de ceux mis en vente à l'arrière de l'ancienne maison de Stanley Bagg implantée au coin de la rue Sherbrooke. Les autres parcelles sont réservées pour la construction de la future École des beaux-arts de Montréal, un projet auquel est associé Ernest Cormier, avec son confrère J. Omer Marchand (1872–1936). Le chantier du studio est dès lors amorcé et la construction de l'édifice s'étale sur plusieurs années, Cormier modifiant le projet au fil du temps. 

Vers 1922, il ajoute un étage afin d'aménager une bibliothèque et un laboratoire de photographie et, en 1928, il l'agrandit.

En 1935, Ernest Cormier, qui s'est fait construire une nouvelle maison, loue le studio à l'École des beaux-arts de Montréal voisine qui y installe un atelier de céramique. 

En 1944, il le vend au gouvernement du Québec. 

Son usage pour l'enseignement se poursuit alors même que l'Université du Québec, fondée en 1969, prend la relève de l'enseignement des arts au niveau supérieur. 

À partir de 1986, le studio accueille des artistes québécois pour des résidences d'un an.

En 1997, le Conseil des arts et lettres du Québec inaugure avec la France un programme d'échanges appelé "Les inclassables" où, chaque année, un jeune artiste français est invité à habiter le studio.

La Société québécoise des infrastructures met en vente le studio en 2016.

**
Article du Devoir, 15 avril 2016



Crédit images d'archives d'Ernest Cormier et du jardin du studio: © Fonds Ernest Cormier, Collection Centre Canadien d'Architecture/Canadian Centre for Architecture, Montréal

story:
“Charting a Course Toward Better Writing.”

Program Directors:

Ruth Ann Zschomler, MFA has worked in journalism and as a magazine writer. Her work has been published on OregonLive.com, in The Oregonian, The Columbian, The Pitkin Review, Canyon Voices, RAIN Magazine, Charisma magazine and several other publications. She has an MFA in Creative Writing from Goddard University. 

Gregory E. Zschomler is the author and/or publisher of more than a dozen books and has written for newspapers and magazines including The Columbian and The Cannon Beach Gazette. He’s an award-winning playwright with a Professional Writing Certificate and a BA in Digital Technologies and Culture from Washington State University. 

Location:

510 West First Street, Aberdeen, WA 98520 
HarborHouseWriters@yahoo.com 

HARBOR HOUSE will exist to support authors and writing students at every level of development by offering workshops, guidance, writer’s services, encouragement, a writing resource library, and space for writers to work and network free from the distractions of home, the office or the coffee shop. 

Our “homey” and relaxed site, seated less than half an hour from some of Washington’s most picturesque beaches (including several locations from the Twilight movie series) and the grand Olympic National Forest, will inspire and delight. 

“A homey kind of place for writers, dreamers and other oddities.” 

Harbor House Offerings:

  • Weekend Writing Workshops up to twice monthly* 
  • Casual Drop-in Writing and Editing Assistance (Mon–.Fri. 11 a.m.–1 p.m.) 
  • Drop-in Writing Time** (Mon.–Fri. 11 a.m.–4 p.m.) 
  • Teen Tuesdays: Free help with writing assignments and essays (2–4 p.m.)
  • Book Club (Monday eve) 
  • Local Writers Group (Thursday evening) 
  • Arts & Craft Classes (occasional Tuesday evenings) 
  • Quarterly Readings 

Other Services such as professional editing, book design, book trailer creation, coaching and publishing services are also available for a fee. 

*How-to, Author Meet & Greets, Indie Publishing Panels, Craft Courses, etc. May require additional registration fees. 

**Includes use of High-speed WiFi, Printing (priced per page), Free Coffee and Tea, Workstations, Basic Consultation, use of the Writer’s Resource Library and more. 

Drop-in Use and Membership Rates: 

  • By-the-Day Fee: $5 
  • 10X Punch Card: $40 
  • Monthly Anytime Pass: $50 (includes our exclusive member e-newsletter) 
  • Yearly Anytime Membership Pass: $499 (includes one free workshop each year and our exclusive member e-newsletter) 

Day Use Amenities: 

  • High-speed WiFi Internet 
  • Ink Jet Printing/ Copies (priced/page) and FAX 
  • The FREE Coffee Drinks and Tea are always on! 
  • Comfy Work Spaces
  • Both Quiet and Social Areas 
  • Basic Consultation 
  • Use of the Writer’s Resource Library 
  • Handy Snacks and Beverages (for sale) 
  • Local Author Bookstore 
  • Charging Stations and more

CAPITAL NEEDS (What we'll use the funds for):

  • Incorporation/Business License  200.
  • Folding Chairs (30 @ $20 ea.)  600.
  • Folding Classroom Tables (6 @ $60 ea.)  360.
  • Outdoor Signage  300.
  • LED Flat Screen Monitor (40”) 300.
  • Lectern  150.
  • Mini Refrigerator 80.
  • Coffee Maker  100.
  • Wireless Network Printer  200.
  • Library & Alcove Furnishings & Decor  650.
  • Resource Materials  100.
  • Insurance  750.
  • Marketing/Promotions  500.
  • Paint  140.
  • Brochure Printing 150. 

Total Goal: $4,300.

Stretch Goal: $5,000 for new Carpet in Conference Room.

Of course ALL Donors will be listed and recognized on a plaque inside the foyer of the Harbor House and on our website, plus you’ll receive an invitation to our Grand Opening Gala on September 24, 2016.

Projected Grand Opening: September 24, 2016 (fingers crossed)

Other Services such as professional editing, book design, book trailer creation, coaching and publishing services are also available for a fee. *How-to, Author Meet & Greets, Indie Publishing Panels, Craft Courses, etc. May require additional registration fees. **Includes use of High-speed WiFi, Printing (priced per page), Free Coffee and Tea, Workstations, Basic Consultation, use of the Writer’s Resource Library and more. Drop-in Use and Membership Rates: 

By-the-Day Fee: $5 


10X Punch Card: $40 


Monthly Anytime Pass: $50 (includes our exclusive member e-newsletter) 


Yearly Anytime Membership Pass: $499 (includes one free workshop each year and our exclusive member e-newsletter) 

Day Use Amenities: 

High-speed WiFi Internet 


Ink Jet Printing/ Copies (priced/page) and FAX 


The FREE Coffee Drinks and Tea are always on! 


Comfy Work Spaces


Both Quiet and Social Areas 


Basic Consultation 


Use of the Writer’s Resource Library 


Handy Snacks and Beverages (for sale) 


Local Author Bookstore 


Charging Stations and more

CAPITAL NEEDS (What we'll use the funds for):


Incorporation/Business License  200.


Folding Chairs (30 @ $20 ea.)  600.


Folding Classroom Tables (6 @ $60 ea.)  360.


Outdoor Signage  300.


LED Flat Screen Monitor (40”) 300.


Lectern  150.


Mini Refrigerator 80.


Coffee Maker  100.


Wireless Network Printer  200.


Library & Alcove Furnishings & Decor  650.


Resource Materials  100.


Insurance  750.


Marketing/Promotions  500.


Paint  140.

Brochure Printing 150. 
Total Goal: $4,300.
Stretch Goal: $5,000 for new
Carpet in Conference Room.
Of
course ALL Donors will be listed and recognized on a plaque inside the
foyer of the Harbor House and on our website, plus you’ll receive an
invitation to our Grand Opening Gala on September 24, 2016.Projected Grand Opening: September 24, 2016 (fingers crossed)

story:
WHAT'S A BADGE OF AWESOME?

A Badge of Awesome is a unique gateway into the DIY craft world. Learn how to embroider. Make something you can be proud of. Know that you've helped someone in need.

We're the first company selling DIY embroidery badges. Not only that, but our kits have everything you need (except scissors) to easily make your custom merit badge in 1-3 hours with no prior sewing/embroidery experience. The best part—20% of the profits generated by every purchase go toward helping refugees of climate change. 

*** We are currently HAND MAKING each of these badge kits and are raising funds to lower the cost of production (which means less expensive badges in the future and more $$ donated. Thanks for your support!) 

INCLUDED:

  • One hand-made 3" badge of your choice from our line (printed on just plain gorgeous fabric)
  • Black embroidery floss
  • One 3" embroidery hoop 
  • One embroidery needle
  • Instruction book 
  • BONUS: Iron-on adhesive backing  

All those icons in the middle of the circle (DO THINGS, the heart, the disco ball, the cupcake; 10 in total) are printed in ink on the fabric, so all you have to do is embroider over the ink, cut it out, and iron or stitch it onto anything you like.

 

WHY REFUGEES OF CLIMATE CHANGE?

Because every day there are more and more people being displaced by the direct and indirect effects of climate change.

While future projects may include helping other social and environmental causes, we want to focus 20% of our profits for this campaign on a cause that's closest to our hearts: climate refugees.

  • Climate change causes flooding and draughts that drive malnutrition and sanitation issues, which means that people in high flood or draught-prone zones will be forced to move from their homes in order to survive.
  • The United Nations estimates that 36 million people were displaced by natural disasters in 2009, the most recent year for which statistics are available. Scientists predict this number could rise to at least 200 million by 2050 — meaning that within 35 years, one in every 45 people in the world could be displaced by climate change.

​

  • According to UNICEF, children will suffer disproportionately from climate change and growing environmental risks, as over half a billion children live in extremely high flood occurrence zones and nearly 160 million live in high or extremely high drought severity zones. 
  • The current regulations and systems already in place are not even close to ready for the type of mass migration that we'll see over the next 30 years. We want to help, and we want to give you the opportunity to help, too.
  • We're waiting to decide on the organization(s) to which we'll contribute until after we see how this campaign goes. Here are some of the ones that we're considering:

​

 

6 Ways You Can Help

1. Donate toward our campaign: buying a badge is ultimately what we hope you do.

2. Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign: you sharing our campaign is the difference between our friends and family contributing to our cause and everyone helping. PLEASE, SHARE THIS WITH YOUR FRIENDS ON FACEBOOK, TWITTER, AND OTHER SOCIAL MEDIA SITES.

3. Collaborate with us: want to work together? Contact us! badgesofawesome@gmail.com

4. Tell us about great causes that support refugees of climate change: we're always open to learning more about organizations that are doing great things. PLEASE, let us know if there's a group of people helping our cause that we might not know about!

5. Read/watch/listen to some of these resources that have inspired us, and help spread the word about climate change refugees:​

  • Read Unicef's document on the impact of climate change on children
  • Listen to This American Life's recent episodes on refugees

    • 592: Are We There Yet?

    • 593: Don’t Have to Live Like a Refugee

    • 560: Abdi and the Golden Ticket

    • 597: One Last Thing Before I Go (Act One)

  • Watch Josh Fox's "How to Let Go of the World and Love Everything Climate Can't Change"

6. Inspire someone to go out and Do Things: however small, change happens when we start.

 

MORE ABOUT BADGES OF AWESOME:

You'll get to choose one of these designs from our Classic theme and can suggest a general color or pattern type, if you'd like. 

If we reach our $12,000 USD goal, then you'll be able to choose from these added options:


 

SUPER EASY TO MAKE!!!

Quick. Crafty. Customizable. Kind. Our badges are for fellow do-gooders that like making things and contributing to worth-while causes.

 

OUR FUNDRAISING GOALS

MINIMUM VIABLE PRODUCT: We need $5000 USD. Here's where it's going:

  • We've already invested around $2000 USD in prototyping materials, so that we can get the badges out to local shops and to any investors on this Indiegogo campaign
  • Because 20% of our profits go toward climate refugee relief efforts, we want to reduce our unit costs and increase amount donated: lower production costs on our part means more money to non-profits. So, we need to be able to buy in wholesale
  • With $5000 USD, we can hit the minimum order quantity to scale our production outside of Portland and contribute more to our cause.

TARGET: We want $7000. Here's why:

  • We started working on our website but quickly realized that, in order to make the site to the same high quality of our product, we're going to need some help.
  • With $7000 we can not only purchase materials wholesale, but we'll also be able to start an expert built online shop for Badges of Awesome. This will allow us to side-step selling our badges through retail shops at wholesale prices and put more money towards helping climate change refugees!

BEST CASE SCENARIO: We would love $12000. Here's what we'd do with that:

  • Looking towards the future, we'd like to sell more than our initial 10 Classic badges. Ultimately, we have 10 more themes that we'd like to carry (with 10 badges per theme). As we start selling badges that better suit each individual's personality, they'll keep getting more and more awesome. 
  • With $12000, we'll be able to do everything above AND increase our product line to specific badges for gamers, nerds, kids, and makers. It's where we wanted to start, but had to hold-off because of the complexity involved. 
  • Extra badge options mean: altering our packaging slightly for each line, a more complicated website, and more work on the manufacturing side. Your contributions will help us raise the bar on our product options without raising our stress-level. 

OUR FAVORITE PERKS!!!

We've created a variety of perks at a few tiers for people who want a Badge Kit and for people who just want to help us increase awareness and raise money for our project.

  • Every perk comes with a small iron-on patch we've made from our badge scraps and a thank you in our future packaging for all of time. Throw us $6, and that's what you'll get. 

    ​

 

  • THE "BUY-LOCAL" 
    We've added the "Visit Portland" badge kit option for Portland-lovers who would like to contribute to our project.


 

  • POSTER CHILD
    We've included a screen printed poster of our DO THINGS MANIFESTO in a couple of our perks options. Put it on your wall and let it help you get things done!

     
  • Want a badge, but don't want to make one? We've got a perk for that, too! For a premium investment, we'll make one (or several) for you. ...donate a whole lot, and we'll use our background in design to make you a beautiful bag with several badges on it! 

 

Risks & Challenges

Before we created Badges of Awesome, we worked in design research and strategy and helped companies solve design and business problems. We've got a background in helping create successful businesses, so you can trust that we're going to see this project through. That being said, there are a few small risks to this project. Here's what we see and how we plan to resolve potential issues:

  • What if you don't reach your $5000 goal?
    • We understand that there's a chance that we may not reach our funding goal on Indiegogo but we're ok with that risk. If we can't meet our financial goal and are unable to pursue bulk, wholesale purchases of our materials, we intend to fulfill our Indiegogo orders and will then continue our project in Portland, growing slowly and selling out of brick and mortar shops.
  • What if you sell too many badges on Indiegogo, and you can't meet orders by December of 2016?
    • Yes, too many orders means slower delivery times. We've already prepped more than 250 badges and are prepared to keep you in the loop, should this campaign become wildly successful.
  • What if your scaling lowers the quality of your product?
    • Thankfully, our product is made of materials that cost us less when we buy bulk, but do not have to be manufactured any differently. Our scaling will not change the quality of materials that we use.
  • What if people want a custom badge kit and you can't make it?
    • Part of our plan for the future is to make fully customizable DIY badge kits a reality. In order to guarantee a quality product and timely delivery for this campaign, we have to stick with the images that we currently offer. As we grow, we'd love to give you the ability to make your own icon, choose your own fabric, and make your badge as truly unique as you are.
